excerpts: Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo).
There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
chicken.author: Ed U.
chicken.review:
It's the tale of two Turtle Towers. It's the best of pho, it's the worst of pho. How can two Turtle Towers be this different in execution and still have the same menu? It's kinda when Patty Duke played identical twin cousins who were total opposites, then they played each other to fool others and knee-slapping hilarity ensues. No hilarity to be found here. Just a standard Vietnamese place in a location that isn't the most pedestrian-friendly at the relatively barren corner of 6th and Bryant. It feels downright suburban compared to the more densely populated Little Saigon location (see my review - http://www.yelp.com/biz/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:idtbVotN081VoyQb9aXurw). 

I ordered the same thing I order at the other location. Jamie W. and I shared the $4.95 Goi Cuon (Spring Rolls), which are impossible to fail with fresh prawns and basil leaves peeking through the near-transparent rice paper. It comes with with addictive peanut dipping sauce (see photo). We both ordered the same entree, the large $7.95 bowl of Pho Bo Dac Biet, which has strips of rare beef, tripe, flank and brisket (see photo). This is where it went wrong - the broth didn't taste right like it was watered down considerably. Pho with only marginally satisfying broth just shouldn't exist. That's when pho should be spelled with an 'F'. 

Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo). There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible. When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it. There's no saving it. Bummer. Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here. The rainbow blend is a plus, but it's too bad that they're coming to a place where the food can be subpar. 

FOOD - 3 stars...darn disappointing compared to the original Turtle Tower in Little Saigon, especially the pho broth 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...feels like a mall court place 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...appeared more focused on turnover 
TOTAL - 3 stars...worth strolling to the Tenderloin to get something more flavorful than what they have here

excerpts: I usually get the chicken pho with giblets, iced Vietnamese coffee and egg rolls on a hungry day.
The broth is like what a super Asian family would cook up at home, add the jalapeños with fish sauce, OMG, writing this makes me want to have another one.
chicken.author: Christopher N.
chicken.review: This is the best comfort food or hang over food ever, I can come to this place every day, except my wife would not be a happy camper... I usually get the chicken pho with giblets, iced Vietnamese coffee and egg rolls on a hungry day. The broth is like what a super Asian family would cook up at home, add the jalapeños with fish sauce, OMG, writing this makes me want to have another one.

excerpts: Finally tried Turtle Tower's infamous chicken noodle (pho) soup.
The pho is more like the Chinese-style "ho fun", fatter in shape and can be less al dente.
I've tried both the small and large bowls - wish there was something in the middle.
The soup was definitely delicious but after having it for the 2nd time there was nothing special that would make me crave it.
No doubt there's MSG.
chicken.author: Jackie C.
chicken.review:
Finally tried Turtle Tower's infamous chicken noodle (pho) soup. The pho is more like the Chinese-style "ho fun", fatter in shape and can be less al dente. I've tried both the small and large bowls - wish there was something in the middle. The soup was definitely delicious but after having it for the 2nd time there was nothing special that would make me crave it. No doubt there's MSG. I've tried a few Vietnamese places in SF and none seem to surpass Y&Y on Clement St. 

Worth trying once to know (or not) why everyone talks about TT. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to try it. Definitely overrated.

excerpts: I have no idea why people love Turtle Tower's chicken pho so much
What really turned me off from this particular location was the time I ordered their steamed chicken (without rice) to go for $8
I opened the container to take a peek at my food before leaving the restaurant because my order felt really light.
Turns out I got less than a chicken leg.
Most of the "meat" I got was skin and bones.
The waiters there were extremely rude when I raised the issue.
The debate got kind of heated my friend asked the waiter if he would have paid $8 for the pathetic chicken platter I got, and he retorted, "Well, I wouldn't have ordered that dish.
Total BS.
In the end, I just asked for my money back and left feeling pissed.
chicken.author: Catherine C.
chicken.review:
THIS PLACE SUCKS. I have no idea why people love Turtle Tower's chicken pho so much, it's utterly bland and tasteless. 

What really turned me off from this particular location was the time I ordered their steamed chicken (without rice) to go for $8+. I opened the container to take a peek at my food before leaving the restaurant because my order felt really light. Turns out I got less than a chicken leg. Most of the "meat" I got was skin and bones. The waiters there were extremely rude when I raised the issue. The debate got kind of heated my friend asked the waiter if he would have paid $8 for the pathetic chicken platter I got, and he retorted, "Well, I wouldn't have ordered that dish." Total BS. In the end, I just asked for my money back and left feeling pissed.

excerpts: For the record the 4 items served on the Wednesday I visited were the Well-done Flank and Beef Brisket Noodle Soup, the Rare Beef Noodle Soup, the Chicken Noodle Soup and Imperial Rolls.
so I ordered a large Rare Beef Noodle Soup and a couple of Imperial Rolls.
As I've come to expect from their Geary location the service here is just as speedy with your food ready in mere minutes after your order is placed.
chicken.author: Wilhelm Y.
chicken.review:
I've eaten at the Turtle Tower Restaurant on Geary Blvd. numerous times, and I've never reviewed them so when I saw that Turtle Tower was opening up a third location on the corner of 6th and Bryant Streets, the space formerly occupied by TEN7M and Quiznos before that, I was giddy with anticipation being that the new location is just a block and a half from where I work.

Fast forward only two short weeks and the restaurant is now open for business serving a limited menu during their soft opening.  The official grand opening is scheduled for next Wednesday, June 1, but I couldn't wait one whole week so as soon as I heard what the limited menu was I stepped in to try it out.

For the record the 4 items served on the Wednesday I visited were the Well-done Flank and Beef Brisket Noodle Soup, the Rare Beef Noodle Soup, the Chicken Noodle Soup and Imperial Rolls.

Those four choices suited me fine as all I really wanted was a hot bowl of beef noodle soup so I ordered a large Rare Beef Noodle Soup and a couple of Imperial Rolls.  As I've come to expect from their Geary location the service here is just as speedy with your food ready in mere minutes after your order is placed.  Accompanied by a lime wedge and some thinly sliced jalapenos plated separately the clear beef broth seemed just a tad too oily (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KAHDxIOccnc1P1m5abjM0A?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w), but once I dove into that bowl the extra oil on top seemed unnoticeable.

The flavor-rich broth was perfectly seasoned and I loved the hint of ginger in it.  The portion of noodles and beef to broth was perfect.  The Imperial Rolls can be ordered as an entrée with vermicelli noodles and fresh veggies, but I elected to order just two on its own (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/KAHDxIOccnc1P1m5abjM0A?select=zdAwClljoGD8NWdEzZUlDg).  These were very good as most deep-fried goodies are, and since I do no deep-frying at home you can bet I'll order these again on a future visit.

So far in 2011 I've done a lot more cooking at home, and brown-bagging my meals for work have become the norm for me, but I know for a fact I can't make pho this good at home so I may need to rethink this whole not-going-out-to-restaurants-too-often thing thanks to the new Turtle Tower Restaurant.

As mentioned by another Yelper in her review some culinary surprises available only at this Turtle Tower location awaits you.  For a sneak preview I've posted the menu in the photos section.  Welcome to the neighborhood, Turtle Tower!  I have a feeling you're going to be seeing me very often.

excerpts: The banh mi (price yet to be determined) includes the standard butter, mayo, cilantro, carrots & jalapenos, then pick your choice of 3 proteins: pate, ham, sausage, fried egg, chicken, and pork.
chicken.author: Luis C.
chicken.review:
Location #3 for Turtle Tower is open for business! (including weekends) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q#XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q The official grand opening is next week Wed. June 1st, 2011.

5 stars seem like a high rating, but there aren't many worthwhile eateries in the area (near Hall of Justice), and the staff are super friendly. So they get extra points for all that. Like most TT fans, my favorite is the Pho Ga.

Those stuck on jury duty will love this addition. I know that they already can get Vietnamese food from Grab N Go across the street, but in my opinion TT's food is way better.

The space is smaller than the branch on Larkin street. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA#4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA During this soft opening week they feature a limited menu, but the best news is that they told me that they'll start making custom made banh mi on the grand opening day. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w#cw_9kbK5kfy_PJj88t3X1Q Note: don't expect it to be as cheap as Saigon sandos.

The banh mi (price yet to be determined) includes the standard butter, mayo, cilantro, carrots & jalapenos, then pick your choice of 3 proteins: pate, ham, sausage, fried egg, chicken, and pork. One of the few to offer a fried egg option, others are Bun Mee, Little Green Cyclo food truck, and Banh Mi Ba Le in Oakland.

Most prices are similar to the Larkin location, including the imperial rolls for $2.15 each (ouch!). Except that most Pho (small $6.20-$7.20, large $7.20-$8.20) and entrees costs about 25 cents more here. Not by much, so I think it's okay.

I'm concerned that this area has no foot traffic on weekends. Except for a few places like McDonald's, most eateries are open weekdays for lunch only. So I don't think it's wise for TT to have weekends hours. A soup business is different from other eateries. The stove remains on for long hours to keep the soup hot, so their utilities bill is high even when they have no customers.

I'd like TT to remain in business, so they need to make some wise decisions from the beginning. Otherwise they'll suffer the same fate as all the previous tenants that went out of business at this corner.

Hours: daily 9am-9pm (revised 2013)

** Update 2013: In case u ever found this shop closed, when u thought it was open. Here's a brief synopsis of the schedule changes. Initial operating hours were 7am-5pm, later extended to 9pm, with a break between lunch and dinner service. Later it changed to continuous service, to match their other locations. Then on January 2013, the schedule was cut to Mon-Sat 10am-4pm, closed Sundays. And in March 2013 they changed their minds again, so it's back to 9pm, including weekends.

excerpts: Sure, the broth was good (not the best, though), but the chicken was chewy.
Not ok.
And, they keep the skin on the chicken.
chicken.author: Erin G.
chicken.review:
What I ate: Goi cuon, pho ga, chrysanthemum tea
Visit date: May 30, 2012
First time? Yes.

Ok, so it's not in the best part of town, but if you're craving some stellar goi cuon, Turtle Tower is the place. I normally get my goi cuon with just shrimp -- the pork just never cut it for me. I forgot to say 'just shrimp' here, but no worries. At the Turtle, they use a succulent grilled pork which makes the goi cuon so much more flavorful. Their sauce was finger-lickin', too -- not too thick and not too runny.

Now, what brought me here was Scoutmob's (Am I allowed to name drop like that?) free pho ga deal. The pho ga was subpar. Sure, the broth was good (not the best, though), but the chicken was chewy. Not ok. And, they keep the skin on the chicken. Maybe that's good for flavoring, but I don't like eating it. 

After soup, I wanted something cold (ice cold!). I had the chrysanthemum tea (from a can) and asked for ice so the sweetness could be diluted (you know me and not liking super sweet drinks). This was a perfect way to end a meal.

Staff is friendly, and they have fancy bag hooks under each table. Plus!

excerpts: - Chicken noodle soup.
Yah, doesn't sound interesting but this is the best chicken pho i've ever had.
chicken.author: Jane A.
chicken.review:
NORTHERN STYLE PHO
(5 stars)

Once you go Northern, you never go back.

- FOOD, delicious pho
- PRICES, affordable
- SERVICE, fast
- AMBIANCE, small

I go to this location because its the less crowded one and I find it to be the cleanest too. I like exposing friends to "northern style" and when they have it they are pretty amazed. Only come here for the soups, the sandwiches were not the business. When I bring people here they never believe me how good it is until you dip into it. 

HEFFER STATUS.

PHO SOT VANG ($6.50) - Beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup. It doesn't look the best but it is SO AMAZING. Can I make love to this soup because it is just that amazing. Hmmm Hmmmm Hmmmm....

PHO GA ($6.50) - Chicken noodle soup. Yah, doesn't sound interesting but this is the best chicken pho i've ever had. You just have to order it to really know what it is all about.

Will I be back? YES YES YES YES YES.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....

excerpts: Went there at 7pm on a Thursday and ordered two large chicken phos.
The bowls came out and had less food than a small.
Definitely couldn't see much noodles or chicken.
It was all soup and chicken skin.
Very disappointed and still got charged full price.
If you're going to be brutally honest about the quality and food, be at least a little honest about the price.
Not cool from someone who's a frequent customer.
chicken.author: Anonymous C.
chicken.review: Been here a few times and have been a fan especially the one on Geary. Went there at 7pm on a Thursday and ordered two large chicken phos. The bowls came out and had less food than a small. Definitely couldn't see much noodles or chicken. It was all soup and chicken skin. Very disappointed and still got charged full price. If you're going to be brutally honest about the quality and food, be at least a little honest about the price. Not cool from someone who's a frequent customer.

excerpts:
Came back and tried the #10 Pho Ga Long or chicken soup with "giblets" which consist of liver, gizzards, and 1 unborn egg, cut in 2 pieces (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-5?select=Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA&userid=DsHsuhUvyyW_75zFcJxkKw#Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA)

Nice amount of chicken, gizzards, and liver.
chicken.author: Andrew C.
chicken.review:
Came back and tried the #10 Pho Ga Long or chicken soup with "giblets" which consist of liver, gizzards, and 1 unborn egg, cut in 2 pieces (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-san-francisco-5?select=Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA&userid=DsHsuhUvyyW_75zFcJxkKw#Ujq4MeJCfNLuNiajT-JSSA)

Food was better, service was worse.

No issues with the noodles this time. Nice amount of chicken, gizzards, and liver. 

Place was 1/2 full when I arrived and it took about 15 minutes to take my order after they took orders for the two tables seated after me. By the time I got my refill of hot tea, I was done eating.

excerpts: I'd highly recommend the chicken noodle soup or (pho GA), if you're feeling adventurous I'd recommend them with the giblets too - they add an extra depth of flavor and interesting texture.
chicken.author: Keyue B.
chicken.review: No idea why this place only has 3 stars, it's amazing. The noodles are soft but you have the options to change them, the broth is extremely flavorful and not because of MSG. I'd highly recommend the chicken noodle soup or (pho GA), if you're feeling adventurous I'd recommend them with the giblets too - they add an extra depth of flavor and interesting texture.

excerpts: The chao ga (chicken porridge) is absolutely awful.
Absolutely no taste, and the rice seemed like 5 days old stale.
But when I told the waiter, he was like ok, and allowed me to order a chicken pho, my usual.
Lol I vow to never venture out of my turtle tower chicken pho obsession!
chicken.author: Annie K.
chicken.review:
The chao ga (chicken porridge) is absolutely awful. Absolutely no taste, and the rice seemed like 5 days old stale. But when I told the waiter, he was like ok, and allowed me to order a chicken pho, my usual. Lol I vow to never venture out of my turtle tower chicken pho obsession!

Tried the imperial rolls too! Very delicious!!! Also the #1 with the beef brisket was amazing too. Still will come back again and again

excerpts: My friend said that the chicken pho was the most famous one -- however, I wanted to have some beef pho (because that's the usual, right?).
chicken.author: Joanne W.
chicken.review:
I was really craving pho one evening after watching a horrible game of the Toronto Maple Leaf losing. I needed to drown my sorrows in some delicious noodle soup. However, I'm new to San Francisco, so I really didn't know where to go. My friend suggested "Turtle Tower" -- but the one in the Tenderloin (then to find out that it was closed). So we ended up in the one in SOMA. 

My friend said that the chicken pho was the most famous one -- however, I wanted to have some beef pho (because that's the usual, right?). I got myself the large, considering how hungry I was, and I wanted tripe -- so I got the one with everything in it? 

Good? Meh. It was not the best pho I've ever had... I've had better -- even in Toronto. I was super duper disappointed. However, I've been hearing that the best pho is in the South Bay - maybe I should venture there.

excerpts: Chicken pho is the BOMB here!
The one with the giblets is the best.
Beware that all chicken meat is with the skin as some people get turn off by this.
The broth is light yet flavorful.
The pho here is also very different and unique only to Turtle Tower.
It is a thinner version of the Chinese chow fun and very smooth.
Because if its texture, it is not soggy at all.
This location is less busy than the main location on Larkin even though it's half the size.
chicken.author: Rose L.
chicken.review: Chicken pho is the BOMB here!  The one with the giblets is the best.  Beware that all chicken meat is with the skin as some people get turn off by this.  The broth is light yet flavorful.  The pho here is also very different and unique only to Turtle Tower.  It is a thinner version of the Chinese chow fun and very smooth.  Because if its texture, it is not soggy at all.  This location is less busy than the main location on Larkin even though it's half the size.

excerpts: Bland chicken and noodles tated old.
I couldn't eat it at all.
This is not the type of food I expect when I order Vietnamese.
I also hate when places have a cash only policy and get attitude when the only cash I have is $100.
Take debit or drop the tude.
Will not return, do NOT reccomend!
chicken.author: Amanda M.
chicken.review:
I am from America but have loved Vietnamese food for most of my life. Little flavor in Pho broth. Bland chicken and noodles tated old. I couldn't eat it at all. This is not the type of food I expect when I order Vietnamese.  
I also hate when places have a cash only policy and get attitude when the only cash I have is $100. Take debit or drop the tude. Will not return, do NOT reccomend!

excerpts: Food-wise, everyone knows Turtle Tower has bomb chicken pho.
It's always tastes the same to me no matter which location I go to
but for service I would prefer the Geary or Tenderloin location.
Service picked up and became more efficient since the restaurant got quite crowded after we got our table.
I guess the servers just haven't figured out how to work as a team yet.
chicken.author: Bonnie S.
chicken.review:
The boyfriend and I came here on a rainy SF night hoping to grab some hot soupy goodness and wait out the evening rush hour commute. Parking was easy to find although traffic was pretty bad since they're right by the entrance to the Bay Bridge.

We walked in around 6:30pm and there was only one couple ahead of us waiting to get seated. The tables were filled save 3-4 tables that were waiting to get bussed. There were two servers - male and female - running around serving up food, taking orders, dealing with the checks but no one took notice of the crowd growing waiting to get seated and the dirty empty tables. I notice that the girl was doing most of the running around - she seated the couple ahead of us - while the boy was just hanging around behind the counter. We stood around for about 10 minutes without getting acknowledged until I had to walk up to the girl and ask if we could get a table for two.

Finally the girl started cleaning up some of the tables while I guess some of the kitchen staff took pity and had to come out to help her. I don't understand what the heck the guy was doing behind the counter doing nothing. 

Food-wise, everyone knows Turtle Tower has bomb chicken pho. It's always tastes the same to me no matter which location I go to but for service I would prefer the Geary or Tenderloin location. Service picked up and became more efficient since the restaurant got quite crowded after we got our table. I guess the servers just haven't figured out how to work as a team yet.

excerpts: The chicken pho is great.
chicken.author: Niniane W.
chicken.review:
The chicken pho is great.  Also the bean drinks.

Don't get the rice dishes.  That was a big mistake I will not be repeating.

We ordered extra chicken pho and no one ever came to clean out the previous bowls we finished. Chatting with coworkers ARE NOT PART OF YOUR JOB. excerpts: my default at turtle tower is always the chicken noodle soup
so i also cant say how the other choices are.
chicken.author: Alex H.
chicken.review:
it doesnt seem as good as the one on geary but considering there arent many other choices for a nice bowl of noodle soup, this is the best option you have in the soma area. 
its a small place so you should also prepare to wait if you get there around noon.

my default at turtle tower is always the chicken noodle soup so i also cant say how the other choices are.

excerpts: Think of it as the best chicken noodle soup you will ever eat.
A fragrant, flavorful chicken broth deepened with the wonderful spices that define pho.
Excellent quality, though quite oily.
Thick, fresh noodles that render you incapable of understanding how any restaurant can serve anything else, finished with a generous topping of green onions and cilantro to brighten the dish.
It's heavenly.
If you were hungover, sick, or depressed, I think this would fix you right up.
It was damn near perfect, but the serving of chicken, though ample, was a tad dry.
Tender, moist chicken would have made this pho absolutely flawless, and would probably have had me on my knees with tears streaming down my face.
I'm kind of glad it wasn't,
so I could keep it together.
But the one flaw could be overlooked, and I'll still consider this one of the best bowls of pho I've ever had.
The portion was huge, too.
We both ordered smalls, which were only $6.75, and were more than satisfied.
I couldn't even finish, which was unusual for me!
chicken.author: Victoria T.
chicken.review:
Turtle Tower is unique because it serves northern-style pho, also known as pho bac. Its simplicity sets it apart from the southern style pho you'd find in most restaurants. You don't get the plate of garnishes considered standard with southern style, so you can't customize your pho. Northern pho is designed to eat exactly as is - though there were actually some sauces on the table and jalepenos brought on the side, so maybe pho bac isn't as strict as I thought. Or Turtle Tower has made a few compromises. Either way.

I always think of parking in San Francisco as a big pain. Parallel parking and meters prevail, and I'm too lazy to deal with it all, so I rarely make it into the city. Parking here wasn't too bad, though. After a few laps around the block, I found a nearby spot. The SoMa location is on a corner easily accessible from the freeway and has a sunny interior, with shades of yellow and cool old photos on the walls. It was noisy, not a place you'd like to sit for hours, but comfortable enough.

The menu features pho, bun, cm, banh mi, and a few special items like chao (rice porridge) and even xoi (sticky rice). Though I've been advised to try the pho sot vang, I had to first try Turtle Tower's specialty, the pho ga. It turned out to be an amazing choice.

Think of it as the best chicken noodle soup you will ever eat. A fragrant, flavorful chicken broth deepened with the wonderful spices that define pho. Excellent quality, though quite oily. Thick, fresh noodles that render you incapable of understanding how any restaurant can serve anything else, finished with a generous topping of green onions and cilantro to brighten the dish. It's heavenly. If you were hungover, sick, or depressed, I think this would fix you right up. It was damn near perfect, but the serving of chicken, though ample, was a tad dry.

Tender, moist chicken would have made this pho absolutely flawless, and would probably have had me on my knees with tears streaming down my face. I'm kind of glad it wasn't, so I could keep it together. But the one flaw could be overlooked, and I'll still consider this one of the best bowls of pho I've ever had. The portion was huge, too. We both ordered smalls, which were only $6.75, and were more than satisfied. I couldn't even finish, which was unusual for me! Thanks, Turtle Tower!


Rating Breakdown:

Taste (13/14):
Broth flavor- 5/5
Noodle & meat quality- 4/5
Garnish selection- N/A (automatic 2 pts)
Portion size- 2/2

Restaurant (14/16):
Service- 4/5
Cleanliness- 5/5
Atmosphere- 3/4
Speed of arrival- 2/2

Total: 27/30

Join the phoventure at www.phoacrossamerica.com

excerpts: Normally I'm a pho tai kinda guy, but I think that their noodle's style, which is softer and flatter than the usual southern vietnamese pho shops, suits chicken better than beef as the textures are a closer match.
My only gripe here is that you will die of thirst since the water cups they give you are for ants, and no one really pays enough attention to constantly refill your water.
chicken.author: Omar M.
chicken.review: Get the spring rolls and pho ga and you're good to go. Normally I'm a pho tai kinda guy, but I think that their noodle's style, which is softer and flatter than the usual southern vietnamese pho shops, suits chicken better than beef as the textures are a closer match. My only gripe here is that you will die of thirst since the water cups they give you are for ants, and no one really pays enough attention to constantly refill your water.

excerpts: I order the Chicken Pho Ga 95% of the time when I come here.
Most of the time when something goes wrong, they skimp on the chicken or give you chicken that is more than 50% skin, other times the soup is too light.
Overall, it's still very good though.
Considering you are getting boneless free range chicken, homemade soup, and fresh rice noodles, it's hard to find anything this healthy as a lunch option that isn't a sandwich or salad.
chicken.author: Mark Y.
chicken.review:
I eat here for lunch very frequently because of the convenient Soma location. Compared to the original Tenderloin location the food here has somewhat less of the home cooked feel and more inconsistency. I order the Chicken Pho Ga 95% of the time when I come here. Most of the time when something goes wrong, they skimp on the chicken or give you chicken that is more than 50% skin, other times the soup is too light. Overall, it's still very good though. Considering you are getting boneless free range chicken, homemade soup, and fresh rice noodles, it's hard to find anything this healthy as a lunch option that isn't a sandwich or salad. 

Also be aware that since the Tenderloin location has closed temporarily until they open the new one a few months from now, they are doing a lot of catering out of the Soma location, which can mean your usual order that is normally served within 5 minutes can take up to 15 depending on what time you are there.

excerpts: The chicken broth smelled funky, I didn't trust the meat.
They also forgot to pack the fresh herbs, siracha, viet Bbq sauce, etc.
chicken soup is basic, customers shouldn't feel compelled to throw it away.
Ever.
chicken.author: John D.
chicken.review:
Had a pretty horrible take out experience. I've eaten a lot of pho in my day, and the bottom line is that the pho ga I picked up was unappetizing. The chicken broth smelled funky, I didn't trust the meat. They also forgot to pack the fresh herbs, siracha, viet Bbq sauce, etc. Actually, I had to flag someone at the restaurant to even pick up my stuff; I stood there behind other patrons for 10-15 minutes waiting for a glance from the busy staff that never came.

I've been to the Turtle Tower on Larkin and had a great meal there. I think I caught these guys on a bad and busy day, but a bad review is justified...chicken soup is basic, customers shouldn't feel compelled to throw it away. Ever.

excerpts: Since I'm too lazy to Uber to the restaurant, I usually get delivery of 3 bowls: 1 dac biet (beef base broth), 1 chicken pho, and 1 egg chicken noodle soup.
chicken.author: Momo M.
chicken.review:
As a Vietnamese gal, every once in a while I would crave pho...

Since I'm too lazy to Uber to the restaurant, I usually get delivery of 3 bowls: 1 dac biet (beef base broth), 1 chicken pho, and 1 egg chicken noodle soup. 

The small bowls are actually REALLY filling (thank you American sizing) so I divide them in half, heat up the broth on stove, place the noodles in a soup bowl and then pour the broth into the noodles @ boiling temperature (3-5min). 

Can't really rate condiments because northern pho is less dressy than southern pho. But I cheat and use that bottle of hot sriracha in my refridgerator. 

My advice is to not order the rice wrapper rolls. They were really dry :( 

Also can't rate service or cleanliness of restaurant because I eat at home. With my cat.

excerpts: Soup was not too salty, but also not the best chicken noodle I've had.
The chicken was slightly juicy but wish there were more of it.
chicken.author: Ting Jung L.
chicken.review:
Hm....I thought this would be SUPER good but was disappointed. I guess this location is not as good as the other Turtle Tower.

Ordered the Pho Ga. LOVE the fat noodles, super chewy. The bowl was actually too small! The soup was spilling over the moment I dipped in my chopsticks. Soup was not too salty, but also not the best chicken noodle I've had. The chicken was slightly juicy but wish there were more of it.

Also ordered the spring rolls and was disappointed again. The lettuce tasted bitter and the rolls were tiny. Shrimp kind of dry and the peanut sauce was average.

PROS
-Pho Ga is above average.
-Hangover food.
-Pretty fast.

CONS
-Cash only
-Super small so the tables are cramped.

excerpts: My boyfriend puts the fish sauce on the jalepenos in the plate and dips the chicken and noodles in the sauce.
The broth is good and I can drink the entire bowl in one sitting.
Very tasty and the noodles compliment it well!
I haven't tried anything else on the menu but Turtle Tower is mostly known for their
chicken.author: Audrey C.
chicken.review:
I would say that Turtle Tower is very unique for a pho restaurant. This is the new chain that just opened and it tastes the same as the other turtle tower restaurants also. 
I came to this site because of the Scoutmob deal of a free regular sized pho ga! 

Very quick service. We got our food within 5 minutes of ordering even though it was pretty busy when we went. 

I ordered the Pho Ga here. The noodles aren't your average pho noodles, rather they are flat and thicker rice noodles. They also don't have the usual siracha or hoisen sauce to put on your pho but they give you a little plate of jalapenos and lemon and you have fish sauce and spicy sauce on your table. My boyfriend puts the fish sauce on the jalepenos in the plate and dips the chicken and noodles in the sauce. The broth is good and I can drink the entire bowl in one sitting. Very tasty and the noodles compliment it well! I haven't tried anything else on the menu but Turtle Tower is mostly known for their Pho Ga. 

A tasty and different treat from your normal pho place!

on paying the bill, we told the cashier and she had no idea what we were talking about, referring to the chicken skins. we also said service/food lousy compared to other branches. she said what other branches.

excerpts: You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg.
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
The pate was kind of weird tasting.
Fried egg was awesome though.
The bread was a softer, more buttery kind.
chicken.author: Sherry L.
chicken.review:
I really enjoy the pho ga at Turtle Tower. But this time I went to the SOMA one for the bahn mi. What can I say, I love banh mi more than pho. I was pretty disappointed with the banh mi, unfortunately. You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg. I asked what happens if I only choose one filling, and the guy said I'll just get more of the one filling.

I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg. I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before. When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was. What happened to more meat? The pate was kind of weird tasting. Fried egg was awesome though. The bread was a softer, more buttery kind. But I think I like the crustier baguette better.

I think I'll stick to the pho ga at Turtle Tower and get my banh mi elsewhere.

EDIT 5/21/2013: Pho Ga = tons of MSG. Avoid!

excerpts: Seriously now...yes, the chicken pho (Pho Ga)  is that good.
I call it a spa treatment for the stomach after a hard day (or night) .
Put another way, this is as good as -maybe even better then- your grandma's chicken noodle soup.
Ya see, most noodle soup places have one or the other: great noodles or great soup.
Rarely does a place have both!
This is why i'm dissing your grandma in such a pubic place.

- if you or your friend are squeamish about chicken skin, you can ask for no skin or just breast meat for a little extra $)  
     -everyone gets a side of sliced jalapenos and lemon wedge.
Dump the jalapenos into the soup (if you are into spicy) and ask for some extra lemon.
I squeeze one wedge in the soup and one in the little condiment dish, where I will add fish sauce and pepper to taste.
This is your "house-made" dipping sauce for your chicken:)
-please note  this is northern vietnamese style
chicken.author: Joseph C.
chicken.review:
First a clarification: 
     I noticed that the 6th street location has significantly fewer stars compared to the original restaurant? I have been to both spots many times and  I'm telling you they are very very similar.  I have no idea what the Yelp others are talking about?  I dare you to a blinded, head to head taste test!

The review:
     Seriously now...yes, the chicken pho (Pho Ga)  is that good.  I call it a spa treatment for the stomach after a hard day (or night) .  Put another way, this is as good as -maybe even better then- your grandma's chicken noodle soup.  Ya see, most noodle soup places have one or the other: great noodles or great soup.  Rarely does a place have both! This is why i'm dissing your grandma in such a pubic place.
     If you are new in town or just visiting SF, here is how I order it;

LARGE PHO GA  (That's their chichen pho of course!)
     - i ask for less noodles because its always more than enough noodles and i want all the beautiful broth i can get.. 
     - if you or your friend are squeamish about chicken skin, you can ask for no skin or just breast meat for a little extra $)  
     -everyone gets a side of sliced jalapenos and lemon wedge. Dump the jalapenos into the soup (if you are into spicy) and ask for some extra lemon.  I squeeze one wedge in the soup and one in the little condiment dish, where I will add fish sauce and pepper to taste. This is your "house-made" dipping sauce for your chicken:)
     -please note  this is northern vietnamese style so you dont get that plate full of bean sprouts and herbs

IMPERIAL ROLL 
     -entree order so you get the lettuce, vermicelli, and herbs to make wraps.
      -order comes with three rolls.  But you can order them individually (without the sides) if you are alone or want a just a little more.
     - I use a drizzle of sriracha in the dipping sauce for a little kick.

VIETNAMESE COFFEE 
     -thank God they still use the individual drip method (i hate it when it comes premixed) 
     -after brewing, I will sometimes carefully spoon out some of the sweetened condensed milk at the bottom of the glass. Then of course stirring together the coffee/milk and pouring it over the ice. (Its sometimes too sweet if you don't...you"ll understand when you see it) 

HOUSE TEA
     - its free and good for you 

Post Scriptum:
     "But joe, my boyfriend is in the mood for beef and he gets kinda crabby when he's hungover?"  I hear ya! No worries, when I'm in that red meat mood, their beef Pho is a very good arternative. But actually i would recommend:

 PHO BO AP CHAO NUOC (Stir-fried Beef with Celery, Carrot, Onion, and Leek) Its pan-fried with the same noodle and then soup is poured over.  I love this one too!

A Fan of Pho

If I could not get fat
I'd eat at turtle tower for every meal.

chicken.review: So amazing I've come here three days in a row. The chicken pho is so good that I dream about it sometimes. I get anxiety from even thinking about ordering anything else because of the intense FOMO I get from not getting the chicken. If I could not get fat I'd eat at turtle tower for every meal.

excerpts: I think its OK... personally I think Chicken Pho you in millbrae is even better.
They don't serve hoisin sauce here btw.
Didn't have to wait for this location.
chicken.author: Stephanie C.
chicken.review: Everyone keeps talking about the pho here.  I think its OK... personally I think Chicken Pho you in millbrae is even better. They don't serve hoisin sauce here btw. Didn't have to wait for this location.

excerpts: The chicken broth was bland and flavorless.
Reminded me of Campbell's canned chicken noodle soup.
The cuts of chicken were all dark meat - fatty and gristly.
No bean sprouts or basil, veggies which are standard with the dish everywhere else.
I ordered the Bún Ch Hà Ni (pork with vermicelli).
The pork came in a bowl with a greasy broth.
chicken.author: Franklin F.
chicken.review:
There are a lot of reviews of this place that essentially rate it as "adequate."  That's being very charitable.  Or maybe people just have very low standards.  I think "terrible" is closer to the mark.  My wife ordered the Ph Gà. The chicken broth was bland and flavorless. Reminded me of Campbell's canned chicken noodle soup.  The cuts of chicken were all dark meat - fatty and gristly. No bean sprouts or basil, veggies which are standard with the dish everywhere else. I ordered the Bún Ch Hà Ni (pork with vermicelli). The pork came in a bowl with a greasy broth.  The Imperial Rolls were badly deep fried - dripping with grease.  

Sunflower (which is only ok, IMHO) is vastly superior.  If you want truly outstanding Vietnamese try Phuong Thao Sunnyvale.  Best I've had in the Bay Area.

excerpts: However the broth and chicken did save the entree!
The chicken is actual just-minced chicken, not some stale pieces chicken breast cutlet that's been sitting around for ages.
It's not dry, it actually quite moist.
That's a plus cause I honestly cannot stand eating dry sandpaper chicken.
chicken.author: Anna F.
chicken.review:
I came here for the free pho go deal from Scoutmob with my brother and friend.

We were seated right away by attentive waiters. They acknowledge the Scoutmob deal and were really nice about it. My brother had trouble getting on the app, but they took his word for it even though we insisted that we properly check in.

When our spring rolls and three hot steaming bowls of pho ga came out, we dug in right away cause we were starved.

The spring roll was a clear rice wrapper of greens, strips of sweet pork, vermicelli, and king shrimp. It comes with a satay-ish sauce with chopped peanuts, which was different cause usually it comes with a clear fish sauce with sweet, pickled carrot. I didn't really like the combination of the two and for four pieces for $5.50, I cannot justify ordering this again.

The pho ga did not have the classic rice vermicelli that is used for pho. I think this was cause we showed up late in the day and after a full week of free pho promotions, they ran out of those noodles.  However the broth and chicken did save the entree! The chicken is actual just-minced chicken, not some stale pieces chicken breast cutlet that's been sitting around for ages. It's not dry, it actually quite moist. That's a plus cause I honestly cannot stand eating dry sandpaper chicken. The stock used for the broth is flavored well enough that I didn't add any condiments, just a squeeze of lime to bring out the tanginess.

One thing I'd like to add is that they are CASH ONLY. They had one of those ATMs that charge a hefty fee for withdrawals and the nearest BoA or Chase is miles away.

Overall, Turtle Tower is good for your quick pho craving. It's not what you would go to for the best pho around SF, but it satisfies you when you're doing jury duty and the only other fare available is McDonald's.

excerpts: $4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage.
As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich.
It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price.
This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70.
Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong.
Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets".
Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines.
A small is $3 and a large is $5.
chicken.author: Dan B.
chicken.review:
Tonight the muuusic seeems so loud!
I wish that! we! could! looose this crowd!
May-be! it's beeetter this wayyy.
We'd hurt each oth-er with the things we want to saaay.
We could have been so gooood togethah,
We could have lived this daannce forevah,
But nowwwww who's goonnnnna daance with meeee?
Pleeeease staaayy!

...And that was upon only having stepped inside the door.

$4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage. I didn't ask, but I figure you can choose the same item for all 3 or do two-and-one if you want.

Note that the sandwich will be JUST the bread and whichever item(s) you select. If you want things that come standard on other restaurants' Vietnamese sandwiches, e.g., mayo, shredded carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, butter, etc., these can be added for $1.55 each.

Yes, each. As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich. It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price. This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70. Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong. #justsayin

Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets". Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines. A small is $3 and a large is $5. I'm definitely returning at some point to investigate.

ICED TEA: I watched the worker make this. It was a glass filled with 3/4 water then topped off with tea. I'm not talking about a glass of water into which were placed tea bags - this was already-brewed tea added to water. I could still taste the tea, but I thought the watering down aspect was odd.

The worker told me this location opened last year. So I'm guessing the 2007 and 2007-2008 ratings plaques on the wall were for the other locations. Also, there was a Scout Mob deal posted at the register, but I didn't read it.

You know I was,
I was wondering, you know, if
if you could keep on, because
the force, it, it's got a lot of power, and
it make me feel like um
it, it make me feel like uh...
WWOOOOOOO!!!

3 1/2 stars.

excerpts: I got the vietnamese sandwich with pate, grilled chicken, and fried egg.
chicken.author: Mandy D.
chicken.review:
Why, why do you disappoint me so. I got the vietnamese sandwich with pate, grilled chicken, and fried egg. I was hoping for the fried egg to be oozing out, but it's cooked well, more like a scramble.

I'm sticking to Grab-N-Go down the block for my vietnamese sandwiches.

excerpts: and I have to ask, "Where's the chicken?!"
They put a tiny portion of chicken meat that would barely qualify for the amount a kid's bowl would have.
chicken.author: Priscilla C.
chicken.review:
First meal in SF after landing, of all the things to eat in SF what do I choose to eat?  Pho.

Parking as it typically is for my spoiled O.C. girl self, horrible.  

It's a small shop and there was just one girl manning the whole place when I went, but it also wasn't busy either.

Pho ga without giblets/innards - broth had a nice deep flavor to it and the noodles were the fresh rice noodles which I thoroughly enjoyed.  However, I ordered the large to share with my friend who wasn't really hungry and I have to ask, "Where's the chicken?!"  They put a tiny portion of chicken meat that would barely qualify for the amount a kid's bowl would have.  

The downside of this spot is that they didn't give me any of basil and bean sprouts that I really like to put in my soup, and the condiments were lacking.  The chili paste was not the good stuff and made my soup taste like a Chinese supermarket.  Thankfully I had spooned that portion off into a small bowl before I put the chili paste in.  

Two stars for the broth and fresh noodles, I think I might come back, but maybe to another location just because I'm curious to see why they have higher ratings.

excerpts: chicken noodle soup that I was looking forward to was way too salty.
we also ordered the stir fried beef with vegetables rice plate.
the beef was also very salty.
very disappointed.
chicken.author: Linda O.
chicken.review: chicken noodle soup that I was looking forward to was way too salty. we also ordered the stir fried beef with vegetables rice plate. the beef was also very salty. very disappointed.

excerpts: Sometimes you just need chicken noodle soup!!!
If you want more veggies, order number 5 with chicken instead of beef.
Then you get celery, carrot, and onions too.
I wish you could just buy the fried chicken leg without the whole rice plate and that they took credit cards bc
I don't often carry much cash.
chicken.author: Patricia A.
chicken.review: Sometimes you just need chicken noodle soup!!! If you want more veggies, order number 5 with chicken instead of beef. Then you get celery, carrot, and onions too. I wish you could just buy the fried chicken leg without the whole rice plate and that they took credit cards bc I don't often carry much cash.

excerpts: Got the chicken pho and oh man...that broth is delicious.
Not too heavy but still full of flavor.
This dish is perfect for cold, rainy days because it'll just make your insides feel warm.
Loved how it had thick noodles rather than the traditional skinny ones.
This dish also gave you like real chicken but my only qualm is that the chicken to noodle ratio was a bit lacking (not enough chicken).
Because the dish was so flavorful, you don't need siracha or hoisen sauce.
chicken.author: Alice C.
chicken.review: Got the chicken pho and oh man...that broth is delicious. Not too heavy but still full of flavor. This dish is perfect for cold, rainy days because it'll just make your insides feel warm. Loved how it had thick noodles rather than the traditional skinny ones. This dish also gave you like real chicken but my only qualm is that the chicken to noodle ratio was a bit lacking (not enough chicken). Because the dish was so flavorful, you don't need siracha or hoisen sauce.

excerpts: I know that the specialty here is Pho Ga (chicken Pho)
but I ordered the Pho Bo Dac Biet (Special Mixed Beef Pho) instead .
The service of the pho was different in that they presented it with just a couple wedges of lemon and some sliced jalapenos .
We didn't get the plate of bean sprouts and Asian basil that you get with pho in other places.
I was told this was because they serve a Northern style of pho unlike the Southern style served in other places.
chicken.author: Sherman B.
chicken.review:
I know that the specialty here is Pho Ga (chicken Pho)  but I ordered the Pho Bo Dac Biet (Special Mixed Beef Pho) instead . The service of the pho was different in that they presented it with just a couple wedges of lemon and some sliced jalapenos . We didn't get the plate of bean sprouts and Asian basil that you get with pho in other places. I was told this was because they serve a Northern style of pho unlike the Southern style served in other places.  There was also no hoisin sauce on the table which is also indicative of the Northern style of pho. 

The soup was more delicate than the usual bowls of pho I've had previously. The broth was lighter and the soup was herb-ier. I added a little fish sauce (that was on the table's condiment cradle) to add a little salt hit to the pho. 

The soup was great and I'd definitely eat here again. I like their lighter brtoh and more delicate soup.

excerpts:
My mom and I ordered:
-Pho ga (Chicken, noodle soup) ($6.20 for a small bowl).
The bowl itself was big enough to share between my mom and I, since we had ordered another dish as well.
The dish has a very simple and subtle flavor to it.
They give a fair amount of noodles and several small pieces of chicken (with the skin on it).
This was alright, but I wish it had a little bit more flavor to it.
chicken.author: Samantha L.
chicken.review:
I visited Turtle Tower with my mom on a Friday afternoon around 1:00 pm. I thought we would miss the lunch rush, but there was still a group of customers hovering around the front entrance. We put our name on the list and the lady let us know that it'd just be 15-20 minutes.  In a little bit less than 15 minutes, we were seated and with menus/water in front of us.  

My mom and I ordered:
-Pho ga (Chicken, noodle soup) ($6.20 for a small bowl).  The bowl itself was big enough to share between my mom and I, since we had ordered another dish as well.  The dish has a very simple and subtle flavor to it.  They give a fair amount of noodles and several small pieces of chicken (with the skin on it).  This was alright, but I wish it had a little bit more flavor to it.  I added jalepenos to try and spice it up a bit.

-Pork rice noodle rolls ($8.70): this was my first time trying this dish (I'm not sure what the Vietnamese name is) and it was pretty good.  The rice rolls are filled with chopped up/ground pork and topped with fried onion pieces.  It also had a pretty simple flavor.  It came with a dipping sauce, but I also requested fish sauce for a little bit more flavor.  It was nice trying both of the sauces. 

-Tricolored drink (about $3).  I usually don't like these types of drinks, but my mom wanted one- so I tried it out.  It was very sweet, but pretty good overall.  There are beans and jelly in the drink.

The restaurant itself is pretty small, with maybe 10 tables or so.  It seems like they do a lot of to-go orders.  There are a lot of people working in the back/kitchen constantly bagging up orders.  I'm not sure if it is worth a wait longer than 15 minutes or if it should be on the 7x7 list- but it's okay. 

Notes:
-Street parking may be difficult during the daytime. I was lucky and found a free two hour space just half a block away.
-Be willing to share a table, it'll cut the wait time.

excerpts: #6 comes with beef but they'll substitute chicken for an extra $1.
chicken.author: Dave B.
chicken.review: If the Pho Ga (#9) isn't interesting enough for you I recommend #6, which has some stir fried vegetables and stir fried noodles for extra flavor.  #6 comes with beef but they'll substitute chicken for an extra $1.

excerpts: Came here and tried different dishes and most memorable is the pho ga (chicken.)
The soup base was excellent and was very hot.
The fun was soft and tender.
The chicken was okay.
chicken.author: T L.
chicken.review:
(See pics)

Review #1022.

Chicken- energizes!
Soup- heats up!

Pho Ga is 3.75 stars but everything else is 3.

Came here and tried different dishes and most memorable is the pho ga (chicken.) The soup base was excellent and was very hot. The fun was soft and tender. The chicken was okay.

They didn't have fresh soy milk on one evening but did have green coconut. However, it was not the whole fruit but was with 3 slices of coconut and coconut juice in water and ice cubes.

The fish patty was a bit salty but added hot sauce made it better and it eas only $2.50.

Other dishes such as vermicelli and seafood chow fun were more Chinese style and were okay.

The take is stick to the pho, especially in one of those chilly San Francisco evenings!

excerpts: The spring rolls weren't the best I've ever had, but the pho and chicken broth were mmMm mMmm mmmm.
chicken.author: Diana K.
chicken.review: I'm not big on pho, but I really liked the pho here. I hear it's even better at the other locations, so I'm eager to check them out. The spring rolls weren't the best I've ever had, but the pho and chicken broth were mmMm mMmm mmmm.

excerpts: The Pho Ga (chicken) is perfect for a cold night or if you're feeling under the weather.
chicken.author: CL S.
chicken.review:
The Pho Ga (chicken) is perfect for a cold night or if you're feeling under the weather. Mix of white and dark meat in a flavorful broth with thick white noodles. 

Cash only.

excerpts: Ordered a # 4 with steak on the side and chicken broth and a Pho
Ga. Pho Ga didn't have much chicken and the broth wasn't that great
plus there was a hair or something like that in the pho ga.
We were given a new pho ga after telling the hostess about it.
chicken.author: Adeline L.
chicken.review: Orange Juice is not exactly fresh squeezed. I watched the hostess get an already squeezed glass out of the fridge. At the other turtle tower they squeeze it right when ordered. Ordered a # 4 with steak on the side and chicken broth and a Pho Ga. Pho Ga didn't have much chicken and the broth wasn't that great plus there was a hair or something like that in the pho ga. We were given a new pho ga after telling the hostess about it.

excerpts: FREE Small pho ga chicken noodle soup (reg $6.20).
I loved it.
Steamed chicken w/ bone $8.20 small
- it was ok, nothing special.
chicken.author: Ann L.
chicken.review:
Went to this location of Turtle Tower Restaurant, 6th & Bryant, because of the Scoutmob deal.  It's a long walk from Civic Center Bart so I don't recommend walking.  Better to drive.

Wait was maybe 1hr, I don't know.  Very long.  We still put our name on the list.

FREE Small pho ga chicken noodle soup (reg $6.20).  I loved it.  B. not so much, he doesn't like their noodles, but I did.

Giu Cuon Spring rolls $5.15 - 2 rolls cut up w/ mint, shrimp, pork, fresh rice paper, peanut sauce on the side. Tasted ok.

I wanted Banh Cuon - it's hard to find everywhere, so was looking forward to it.  Sold out when I went.  So sad.

Steamed chicken w/ bone $8.20 small - it was ok, nothing special.  Lemon/salty dipping sauce on the side.

Iced condensed milk Vietnamese coffee $3.20 - That's pricey for Vietnamese iced coffee.  Tasted ok.

Our total about $18 before tip.  They take credit card.  One unisex bathroom in the back.

Closed Sun
M-Sat 10-9

Website:
www.turtletowersf.com

excerpts: I also love how they de-bone the chicken
and it was boiled just like how my mom makes it.
chicken.author: Vanessa K.
chicken.review:
SCOUTMOB!!! For free pho ga it's pretty damn tasty. The broth has definitely been stewed for hours and there probably was 20+ chickens' bones in that soup. Yum! I also love how they de-bone the chicken and it was boiled just like how my mom makes it. I wish it came with bean sprouts, maybe for the paying customers they will provide it in the future. 

The imperial rolls (fried egg rolls) are ok. Nothing to rave. I don't think I'll order it again as it was expensive. I think I'll just go for the pho ga if I'm craving it. Nothing else on the menu looked impressive.

excerpts: This northern-style, chicken broth pho really hit the spot.
It tastes much lighter, and yet, has so much flavor.
Some citrus in the broth also enhances the soup.
The noodles were also just the right texture.
chicken.author: Kazu O.
chicken.review:
I'm not a big fan of pho, really. I never crave it. I've never said "Wow, this is great!"

Well, Turtle Tower.. you've changed my mind. Perhaps I was starving after a soccer game when I happened to stumble into here.. but yes, this was pho that actually made me exclaim, "Wow!" 

This northern-style, chicken broth pho really hit the spot. It tastes much lighter, and yet, has so much flavor. Some citrus in the broth also enhances the soup. The noodles were also just the right texture. Just tough enough to not be chewy, and not disgustingly soggy.

I'm definitely coming back! Next time.. we'll see how this place works as a hangover cure!

excerpts: Chicken Pho, spring rolls and imperial roll were all excellent.
Location is clean and has a nice modern feel.
The service was fantastic, so sweet and accommodating.
Highly recommended!
chicken.author: Patrick S.
chicken.review: Chicken Pho, spring rolls and imperial roll were all excellent.  Location is clean and has a nice modern feel.  The service was fantastic, so sweet and accommodating.  Highly recommended!

excerpts: I get the same thing every time, pho ga (chicken).
chicken.author: Rosalyn C.
chicken.review:
I love love love a steaming bowl of pho on a foggy cold SF day which is like 285 days a year....  After hitting most of the well reviewed spots on Yelp, Turtle Tower is hands down my favorite for taste.  I get the same thing every time, pho ga (chicken).  The broth is light, flavorful, and very tasty, the noodles are thicker than the typical vermicelli, but I like it more, all the accouterments condiments (cilantro. & onion) are already added except for hot peppers, no side of basil & bean sprouts, but I don't miss them one bit.

This is like comfort food from granny if granny lived in Hanoi.  I look at this as my healthy alternative to Ramen :).

Other locations are equally tasty in the Tenderloin & Richmond.  The SoMa location has the easiest parking.  Cash only, service is fast but zero frill.

For hipper versions of tasty pho that feels less authentic but there is decor & better service, I also like Tin on Howard  & Mau in the Mission.

excerpts: Ok, I gave it another try, Was told that the Chicken noodle soup was the truth.
Yes indeed, it was good.
Come to find out that this is their pride and joy.
If you do happen to eat here, order this for sure.
The only thing they forget to add when taking to go orders is the lemon pepper sauce, which enhances the soup.
Double check to make sure they throw that in.
chicken.author: Pedro N.
chicken.review: Ok, I gave it another try, Was told that the Chicken noodle soup was the truth.  Yes indeed, it was good.  Come to find out that this is their pride and joy.  If you do happen to eat here, order this for sure.  The only thing they forget to add when taking to go orders is the lemon pepper sauce, which enhances the soup.  Double check to make sure they throw that in.

excerpts: Of course I stuck with the only thing I really know, their Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup).
chicken.author: Lauren K.
chicken.review:
The one on Larkin was way better than this.

I've been craving Turtle Tower for awhile now and decided to go to this location just because it closes later than the one on Larkin. They have a dinner menu and a lunch menu but you can order from either one. Of course I stuck with the only thing I really know, their Pho Ga (chicken noodle soup).

The Pho Ga broth was a bit salty than I last remembered it. So salty that I poured a quarter of my water in my bowl and probably could have gotten away with pouring the rest of my water in too (well maybe not). The noodles were also mushy and overcooked. Probably the reason why I didn't really feel like finishing it all up.

Their service was good. She made sure that right when I put my menu down, she would take my order so I wasn't left waiting.  I loved how they poured us water using the Brita Filter.

excerpts: The place is not the nicest but definitely the best chicken noodle soups in the neighborhood.
I also like the fresh squeezed orange juice.
A great place when you feel something not heavy and soupy.
chicken.author: Shannon J.
chicken.review: The place is not the nicest but definitely the best chicken noodle soups in the neighborhood. I also like the fresh squeezed orange juice. A great place when you feel something not heavy and soupy.

excerpts: This isn't the best chicken pho I had
but I think it does its job.
Friends of mine told me that they are known for their chicken pho
so I had to give it try.
I went to the TL location first and found out there was a location closer to where I live.
I always order the chicken and giblets pho with a Vietnamese ice coffee!
I think Pho is the perfect cure for being sick.
chicken.author: Alister L.
chicken.review:
This isn't the best chicken pho I had but I think it does its job.  Friends of mine told me that they are known for their chicken pho so I had to give it try.  I went to the TL location first and found out there was a location closer to where I live.   I always order the chicken and giblets pho with a Vietnamese ice coffee!  I think Pho is the perfect cure for being sick.  This place is cash only but the quick service is always a bonus.

I also really like their dessert glass  counter near the cashier.  All the noms!

excerpts: I came here with a friend because she had a scoubt mob deal...free chicken noodle soup!
I expected it to be a small bowl of soup, but it was actually quite big and good.
It's a Vietnamese version of the dish.
chicken.author: Margaret R.
chicken.review:
I came here with a friend because she had a scoubt mob deal...free chicken noodle soup! I expected it to be a small bowl of soup, but it was actually quite big and good. It's a Vietnamese version of the dish. It definitely was not pho though.

The service was nice, but seemed a bit aggressive. I didn't like how they made us give them our email addresses. 

The imperials rolls were small. It cost $2 something for one teeny roll. Poo!

All in all, it was decent - probably because I only paid $4 including tip.

excerpts: We all opted for the PHO GA and I got the PHO GA LONG (with chicken gizzards).
Although we all ordered a small, the portion was pretty decent, I wasn't able to finish mine.
It came with a generous amount of rice noodle, overwhelming amount of green onions, a handful of chicken slices, and a limited amount of gizzards.
Although it wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing either.
chicken.author: Ada C.
chicken.review:
Came here on a late Saturday afternoon and the place was empty. Minutes later, a couple more parties trickled in, so I guess we brought business with us.

We all opted for the PHO GA and I got the PHO GA LONG (with chicken gizzards). Although we all ordered a small, the portion was pretty decent, I wasn't able to finish mine. It came with a generous amount of rice noodle, overwhelming amount of green onions, a handful of chicken slices, and a limited amount of gizzards. Although it wasn't bad, it wasn't amazing either. The broth seemed watered down and a bit lacking in flavor. 

Aside from the "Northern style pho" (thicker noodles) that distinguishes this place from its counterparts, I can honestly say that Turtle Tower did not leave much of an impression.

excerpts: After Anna explained that this wasn't your "typical" pho, and done in the style of North Vietnam, where they specialized in things like chicken noodle soup, I ended up ordering a pho ga, and getting an imperial roll to share.
The imperial roll, while tasty, was a surprisingly small bite-size portion (given the price), and greasy to boot.
chicken.author: Johnny W.
chicken.review:
Finding myself frequently in the mood for pho lately, Anna D and I dropped by Turtle Tower on her suggestion, seeing as I'd been avoiding them up until now. For what reason I did this is unclear now, and unfortunate, as it turns out that the food here is actually rather tasty.

After Anna explained that this wasn't your "typical" pho, and done in the style of North Vietnam, where they specialized in things like chicken noodle soup, I ended up ordering a pho ga, and getting an imperial roll to share. The imperial roll, while tasty, was a surprisingly small bite-size portion (given the price), and greasy to boot. The pho ga however, was enjoyable; it did, however, become fairly salty towards the end (probably a result of sitting in the broth so long).

And while I think they're a tad higher priced than most places, I can certainly see myself coming back for their noodles.

excerpts: Now that I've managed to have the beef and chicken pho many times, I do have to say that their broth is something different from most standard pho places.
It does have a bit more umami flavor (rather than just pure salty) in the chicken broth.
My wife adores them because she says their chicken broth, of all pho places, tastes the most "clean".
chicken.author: Frederick L.
chicken.review:
Now that I've managed to have the beef and chicken pho many times, I do have to say that their broth is something different from most standard pho places.  It does have a bit more umami flavor (rather than just pure salty) in the chicken broth.  My wife adores them because she says their chicken broth, of all pho places, tastes the most "clean".  

The sandwiches are good (I like the options to choose 3 proteins), and the summer rolls and egg rolls are solid.  Overall, a pretty solid menu.  

Tips: Cash only.  Parking is a pain around that area (especially around rush hour), so if you're super lazy and willing to pay a $10 fee, you can use trycaviar.com to get them to deliver it to you.  They are a little stingy with their condiments, so make sure you ask for them.

excerpts: Ga. The Chicken Noodle Soup.
The noodles are soft and not too hard.
The chicken is not too dry.
And the soup has a great taste.
chicken.author: Alice T.
chicken.review:
I LOVE Turtle Tower. I think it is THE best pho I have ever had. 

This place is northern Vietnamese food. Not your typical pho. So if you come in, don't expect it to be the skinny noodles with bean sprouts/basil and lime. They don't give you that extra condiments.

My favorite from there is the Pho Ga. The Chicken Noodle Soup. The noodles are soft and not too hard. The chicken is not too dry. And the soup has a great taste. I love coming here when I'm sick, cause it clears up my nose and makes me feel better. 

Every time I am in SF, especially if it is on a cold day, I will try to make my way to go to one. They have three locations, the one I usually go to is the one in Richmond. However, I was at AT&T Park and the one on 6th St. was closer.

If your gonna eat pho and your in the city, I would say go there. It's too good to not try it out.

excerpts: First I must admit that I've been eating Vietnamese food for the past 15 years and I never ever order chicken pho, I always go for the beef.

We ordered the chicken pho and the lemongrass shaking beef bun (noodle), and a Vietnamese ice coffee 

chicken pho: flavor is okay but nothing to write home to.
maybe it's good for when you are sick and want chicken soup
chicken.author: Betty C.
chicken.review:
What is all the rage about this place? 

First I must admit that I've been eating Vietnamese food for the past 15 years and I never ever order chicken pho, I always go for the beef. 

Apparently, I've been eating southern Vietnamese food all my life because Turtle Tower touts itself as a Northern Vietnamese restaurant. 

We ordered the chicken pho and the lemongrass shaking beef bun (noodle), and a Vietnamese ice coffee 

chicken pho: flavor is okay but nothing to write home to. maybe it's good for when you are sick and want chicken soup but I wouldn't want this normally 

lemongrass shaking beef bun-horrible. the beef was gross, the noodle was gross, the sauce was gross. I hardly ate any of it and it's a big bowl for $8.20. If we come back again, I will NEVER order this dish. 

The highlight of my meal was the Vietnamese ice coffee that came in the actual french press. Amazing. The only bummer was that t was $3.50 for a little cup =(

excerpts: My recommendations are definitely a banh mi: any way you like it, and their chicken pho.
very flavorful and the noodles are definitely refreshing from the more norm vietnamese restaurants.
chicken.author: Sheena S.
chicken.review:
Open early. 

I'm a little surprised after reading other reviews because I feel like I receive nothing but 5 star service!

I've never had to wait, my food is always hot (even when I'm running late from meetings)

They offered a great coupon during their "Grand Opening" (a little upset they didnt have a full menu this day, was still their "limited menu". Even if they did give a deal, I've never felt like I had to use it because I find the food cheap already!

My recommendations are definitely a banh mi: any way you like it, and their chicken pho. very flavorful and the noodles are definitely refreshing from the more norm vietnamese restaurants.

excerpts: I tried the chicken pho, which was just ok.
The noodles were overcooked.

Also tried the fresh spring rolls with shrimp & pork, served with a peanut sauce, and those were pretty good -- they used more lettuce and less vermicelli noodles, but the portion size was reasonable and the presentation was nice.
chicken.author: Beatrice W.
chicken.review:
This place IS clean for a pho joint!  And the service was good -- when we left we were thanked by multiple staff members for our business.

I tried the chicken pho, which was just ok.  The noodles were overcooked.  Also tried the fresh spring rolls with shrimp & pork, served with a peanut sauce, and those were pretty good -- they used more lettuce and less vermicelli noodles, but the portion size was reasonable and the presentation was nice.

excerpts: Chicken pho was okay
; it was too bland for me after about 5 spoons.
I had to spice mine up with lime, pepper, fish sauce, and sriracha
lol!
Basically very light and clean chicken broth soup with noodles and small pieces of chicken.
I really didnt like the haw fun noodles
, i prefer the traditional pho vermicelli.
There was not enough chicken in my soup either, they really skimp on the chicken.
And what i don't like was they put little pieces of chicken fat strips in the soup..
that's kind of disgusting
The broth was nicely made with chicken flavor..but how much chicken broth can you really drink?
I definitely prefer regular pho...not worth the hype at all!
chicken.author: Terence N.
chicken.review:
Chicken pho was okay; it was too bland for me after about 5 spoons.  I had to spice mine up with lime, pepper, fish sauce, and sriracha lol!  Basically very light and clean chicken broth soup with noodles and small pieces of chicken.   I really didnt like the haw fun noodles, i prefer the traditional pho vermicelli.  There was not enough chicken in my soup either, they really skimp on the chicken.  And what i don't like was they put little pieces of chicken fat strips in the soup..that's kind of disgusting no?

The weird thing was my friend ordered his with no cilantro..the soup tasted better but it was also oiler.  It was almost like a different soup base because his was more cloudy and mine was a cleaner clearer broth.  But we both ordered the same thing!   

I would only come here if i was sick and needed a light and clean broth.  The broth was nicely made with chicken flavor..but how much chicken broth can you really drink?  I definitely prefer regular pho...not worth the hype at all!

excerpts: The Chao Ga (Chicken Porridge) wavers at 3stars...
Its on the thicker side than what I'm used to, and the chicken was kinda dried out and bland.... definitely not as good as what my mom makes at home, but it will do.
chicken.author: Lana N.
chicken.review:
Stick to their tried and true and you won't leave too disappointed.

Stumbled in on New Years Day and was promptly seated and fed. Thank you Asian joints for always being reliably open on any holiday! We went with not Pho for some reason... I guess we were feeling adventurous this new year, and it was a mixture of hit and miss. 

The Spring Rolls are solid 3stars... I'd get them again if ever in the mood.

The Chao Ga (Chicken Porridge) wavers at 3stars... Its on the thicker side than what I'm used to, and the chicken was kinda dried out and bland.... definitely not as good as what my mom makes at home, but it will do.

The Beef Stew in Red Wine Sauce??... I've never seen anything like it. We were thinking it was going to be more like Bo Ca Ri (Beef Stew Curry)... but it was beef stew in a strange artificial looking red wine sauce that tasted purely like corn starch - eeck, pass!

From my experience, I'd say the Tenderloin location is probably better, but for being conveniently located down the street for our lazy asses... this place is a-okay.  Just remember that it is cash only like all other Asian hole-in-the-walls.

excerpts: The chicken pho here is so good!
Perfect comfort good!
chicken.author: Xue C.
chicken.review: Usually no line at this location. Food comes out fast! The chicken pho here is so good! Perfect comfort good!

excerpts: This review is just for the pho ga (chicken pho, number 9).
The broth is amazing.
Stick with the chicken pho
and you're good to go!
chicken.author: Dina H.
chicken.review:
This review is just for the pho ga (chicken pho, number 9).  The broth is amazing.  It's our go to hangover meal.  

The first time I went to Turtle Tower, I ordered regular beef pho.  I remember being really unimpressed ... and it was just different from the pho I was used to.  I haven't ordered it since.  Stick with the chicken pho and you're good to go!

excerpts: I love this restaurant because I love chicken pho and my little brother loves turtles - so I always think of him whenever I eat here.
Also, they take credit card and the food comes out in 10 min.
I tried my friends dishes and they all tasted good
chicken.author: Gina H.
chicken.review: I love this restaurant because I love chicken pho and my little brother loves turtles - so I always think of him whenever I eat here. Also, they take credit card and the food comes out in 10 min. I tried my friends dishes and they all tasted good

excerpts: I honestly haven't had a better pho ga (chicken noodle soup) anywhere other then Turtle tower.
However, I haven't been to Vietnam
and I'm not declaring that it's the best ever
chicken.author: Stephanie K.
chicken.review:
I honestly haven't had a better pho ga (chicken noodle soup) anywhere other then Turtle tower. However, I haven't been to Vietnam and I'm not declaring that it's the best ever; It's just the best among the ones I've tasted in my lifetime. 

The broth is so simple and clean, yet packs the right amount of flavor for the noodles. 

At this particular location I only ordered my pho ga 'to go'. With a quick scan of the place, it seems to be a lot cleaner then the original location out in the tenderloin. I did realize recently that that location has gone through a renovation.

I also ordered the pork chop over rice. This dish however is pretty typical and doesn't quite stand out as anything out of the ordinary.

Overall thoughts: Definitely worth coming to Turtle tower for their pho ga! Getting it 'to go" is a great option as they separate everything for you to combine at your own convenience.

excerpts: My usual thought process is if I want chicken pho fast
and I'm in SoMa
, I go here to get pickup (I live a block away).
If I want regular pho and have some time, I go to Miss Saigon.
chicken.author: Ray N.
chicken.review: Decent pho ga, but it's not as good as the original location in the Tenderloin. It is also on the expensive side and not necessarily better than other pho options. My usual thought process is if I want chicken pho fast and I'm in SoMa, I go here to get pickup (I live a block away). If I want regular pho and have some time, I go to Miss Saigon.

excerpts: Get the beef or chicken pho.
Their broth is really good, but I still prefer Kevin's Noodle House's broth best.
This is a close second.
I didn't order the bahn-mi, so I can't review it.
chicken.author: Stephen F.
chicken.review:
Get the beef or chicken pho.  Their broth is really good, but I still prefer Kevin's Noodle House's broth best.  This is a close second.  I didn't order the bahn-mi, so I can't review it.
