Le bf and I visited this Soma location on a weekday evening for dinner. We ordered:
1. Small chicken pho ($9)
2. Small pho with rare beef ($9) (because they wouldn't substitute anything for anything else or else I would have got the pho with rare beef, well done beef and tripe)
3. Thai Tea ($4.25)
4. Fried Imperial Rolls with Vermicelli Noodle, Lettuce, Mint and Cilantro ($11.50)

We had some doubts before coming from reading what other people wrote on Yelp. Be warned, the other things they give you to accompany your pho are jalapeno slices and 1 wedge of lime each. Because people seemed to really like the chicken pho, that is what le bf got. He thought that is was pretty good when compared to other chicken pho that he has had. 

I normally get pho with rare beef and tripe. This place didn't have that combo. I tried to order the rare beef, well done beef and tripe and instead of well done beef, I wanted to get another portion of rare beef. I was sadly informed that they don't do any kind of substitutions. That is unfortunate. My pho came with 5 very small pieces of rare beef. I would have expected a bit more, even in SF. Overall, I've had richer broth, and the pho was just ok. It was edible, but nothing special. 

The Thai tea was laughably small for $4.25. It was just slightly larger than the small water glasses they provided. Total rip off. It tasted good, but had I known how large the cup was going to be, I wouldn't have ordered it. 

We also ordered the imperial rolls, which came out after both of us had finished our small bowls of pho. On the plate, we saw 3 tiny imperial rolls with 2 leaves of lettuce, some mint, cilantro, noodles, and dipping sauce. they didn't even give us enough lettuce leaves to eat our  If we ordered just one imperial roll, it was have been $3.25 each. If you were thinking about it, don't order it. The imperial rolls were about 3.5 inches long and very skinny, like if you tied 2 of your skinniest fingers together.

For more than $40 (including tax and tip), this was super, super expensive Vietnamese food. When we got into our Uber, the first thing le bf said was "that was super expensive". Even though we finished every single item, I was still hungry so we stopped by Taco Bell afterwards so that I could fill my tummy with the 3 taco combo. Needless to say, we will NOT be back. And we can't recommend this place unless you want to be willingly ripped off.

excerpts: I ordered the chicken with chicken giblets pho ga and nem cua fried imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles and lettuce.
Let me start by saying that the broth from the pho actually tasted like chicken.
The limited spice and fish sauce added to the broth was not too salty and overpowering that it did not take the essential chicken taste away.
The rice noodles were wide and soft.
I normally like my noodles al dente, but in this particularly case, it matched really well with the broth and meat.
Finally, the chicken was pulled and cut into small bite size pieces with a mixture of dark and white meat.
It was a good contrast between the soft and more flavorful dark meat verus the firm but subtle taste of the white meat.
It does not regulate the amount of time the chicken is outdoors, the size of the outdoor space, or its food source.
fried imperial rolls.author: Chris W.
fried imperial rolls.review:
Turtle Tower was my introduction to northern-style Vietnamese pho.  Previously, I didn't even know such a thing even existed.  And man was it delicious.  

I ordered the chicken with chicken giblets pho ga and nem cua fried imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles and lettuce.  Let me start by saying that the broth from the pho actually tasted like chicken.  The limited spice and fish sauce added to the broth was not too salty and overpowering that it did not take the essential chicken taste away.  The rice noodles were wide and soft.  I normally like my noodles al dente, but in this particularly case, it matched really well with the broth and meat.  Finally, the chicken was pulled and cut into small bite size pieces with a mixture of dark and white meat.  It was a good contrast between the soft and more flavorful dark meat verus the firm but subtle taste of the white meat.  The giblets added a fulfilling crunch to every bite. 

The nem cua was fried to perfection.  And in this particular case, I could actually taste the crab meat (There are a lot establishments elsewhere that would cheap out and increase the ratio of the pork filling). When eaten with the noodles and lettuce and dipped in the fish sauce, it's elevated to an whole new level.  Definitely recommend trying this dish here at least once.

What's keeping me from giving this 5 stars was that the portion size were too small.  I judge a restaurant by the culinary experience I received versus the amount I paid.  I have no problem giving a shabby "normal" place a perfect score if the value accurately reflects it.  In this case I left the restaurant not hungry but not fulfilled.  In addition I don't think claiming that the chickens were raised "free-ranged" can justify the increase in price.  The USDA states that free-range only means that the animal has access to outdoors.  It does not regulate the amount of time the chicken is outdoors, the size of the outdoor space, or its food source. 

In conclusion I definitely recommend this place to any pho lover.  I'm sure there are many non-Vietnamese people that would appreciate knowing there is a different style of pho out there.  Just don't expect to be stuffed of full when you finish your meal.

excerpts: I wish you could just buy the fried chicken leg without the whole rice plate and that they took credit cards bc
I don't often carry much cash.
fried chicken leg.author: Patricia A.
fried chicken leg.review: Sometimes you just need chicken noodle soup!!! If you want more veggies, order number 5 with chicken instead of beef. Then you get celery, carrot, and onions too. I wish you could just buy the fried chicken leg without the whole rice plate and that they took credit cards bc I don't often carry much cash.

excerpts: I got the beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup and loved its strong taste.
The soup was very savory and the taste of wine was moderate.
I especially loved the beef because it was so tender and immediately melted in my mouth.
This dish is definitely for you if you love a fusion of different flavors.
I would also highly recommend adding the lime in any of their soups to give the flavor a little kick.
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Leslie C.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review: Absolutely lovely! I got the beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup and loved its strong taste. The soup was very savory and the taste of wine was moderate. I especially loved the beef because it was so tender and immediately melted in my mouth. This dish is definitely for you if you love a fusion of different flavors. I would also highly recommend adding the lime in any of their soups to give the flavor a little kick.

excerpts: A minus point is the "Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Pho".
The broth from  is too reddish and exotic (I think the restaurant put too much wine into the broth and little spice powder), which was a bit not too eye-catching.
Normally the ideal color for this dish would be orange yellow.
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Pemi N.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review:
As a Vietnamese student from Hanoi studying in San Francisco, I think this restaurant is 80% authentic of Hanoi cuisine. I would recommend tasting the "Combination of Rare Beef, Tripe, Well-done Beef Pho", because the broth and the noodles from the rare beef pho are flavorfully complemented. The beef was well done. However, I think there should be more herbs like culantro or basil for a perfect bowl of Pho.

A minus point is the "Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Pho". The broth from  is too reddish and exotic (I think the restaurant put too much wine into the broth and little spice powder), which was a bit not too eye-catching. Normally the ideal color for this dish would be orange yellow.

excerpts: Beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup.
It doesn't look the best
but it is SO AMAZING.
Can I make love to this soup because it is just that amazing.
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Jane A.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review:
NORTHERN STYLE PHO
(5 stars)

Once you go Northern, you never go back.

- FOOD, delicious pho
- PRICES, affordable
- SERVICE, fast
- AMBIANCE, small

I go to this location because its the less crowded one and I find it to be the cleanest too. I like exposing friends to "northern style" and when they have it they are pretty amazed. Only come here for the soups, the sandwiches were not the business. When I bring people here they never believe me how good it is until you dip into it. 

HEFFER STATUS.

PHO SOT VANG ($6.50) - Beef stewed in wine sauce noodle soup. It doesn't look the best but it is SO AMAZING. Can I make love to this soup because it is just that amazing. Hmmm Hmmmm Hmmmm....

PHO GA ($6.50) - Chicken noodle soup. Yah, doesn't sound interesting but this is the best chicken pho i've ever had. You just have to order it to really know what it is all about.

Will I be back? YES YES YES YES YES.

JABA APPROVED. Until the next review....

excerpts: I especially like the Ph St Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup).
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Ali A.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review:
Turtle Tower on Larkin street is awesome. They have some of the best Pho I've had in the city. I especially like the Ph St Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup).

Turtle Tower on 6th street?...not so much. I got all happy that they opened up a new Turtle Tower that was closer to my house but after coming here 3 times now, I have to say I'm kinda disappointed with the quality of the food. It's still decent but just not nearly as good as the one on Larkin street. 

There's usually a line to be seated but once you're in, the service is generally pretty good and fast. 

Bottom line...if you love Pho, you gotta check out Turtle Tower but if you have the choice, go to the other branch on Larkin street instead.

excerpts: (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup) is one of the most unique soups i've ever had, with super tender pieces of beef.
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Susan L.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review:
my go-to place when it's chilly and i'm in need of something soupy...oh wait, that's like every night in SF :D  what's even more awesome is that the 6th st. location is only 2 blocks away from me!

the pho ga broth is AH-MAAAAAA-ZZZZZING:  clear, flavorful, and fresh-tasting.

the Pho Sot Vang (Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup) is one of the most unique soups i've ever had, with super tender pieces of beef.

we've even mixed it up and gotten the banh mi a few times.  TASTY! (albeit no contest with saigon sammies)

not sure why TT gets a bad rap sometimes.  it is what it is, and it doesn't pretend to be something it's not.  i'm always satisfied when i walk out of there and counting down the hours until it's appropriate to go back for another bowl of hot steamy delicious soup ^_^

excerpts: and my bf had #5 (Pho Sot Vang - Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup).
Both were great.
I loved my soup!
The flavors were superb and  I felt full afterwards.
Too bad they didn't accept cards and the atm was broken... had to walk a few blocks to the ATM.
beef stewed in wine sauce.author: Yanika S.
beef stewed in wine sauce.review: I had #11 (Bún Thang - Chicken, Finely Sliced Egg, Ground Pork, & Shrimp Paste Vermicelli Noodle Soup) and my bf had #5 (Pho Sot Vang - Beef Stewed in Wine Sauce Noodle Soup). Both were great. I loved my soup! The flavors were superb and  I felt full afterwards. Too bad they didn't accept cards and the atm was broken... had to walk a few blocks to the ATM.

excerpts: We ordered a banh mi sandwich and the sticky rice with steamed chicken and Chinese sausage.
Everything about the dish was poorly executed: cold pieces of steamed chicken you could tell weren't fresh and Chinese sausage carelessly sprinkled over a bed of room temperature sticky rice.
Everything about the dish was poorly executed: cold pieces of steamed chicken you could tell weren't fresh and Chinese sausage carelessly sprinkled over a bed of room temperature sticky rice.
steamed chicken.author: Cindy Y.
steamed chicken.review:
Unfortunately, I was very disappointed with this place. Despite the lackluster Yelp reviews, I decided to give this place a try since it was conveniently located and I had noticed it had a decent amount of traffic (maybe just coincidence) the couple of times I passed by it.

We ordered a banh mi sandwich and the sticky rice with steamed chicken and Chinese sausage.

The banh mi sandwich was very average -- nothing special. The meat did not have any flavor, the pickled vegetables were not particularly fresh, and the bread was nothing but an edible envelope for bland ingredients.

The sticky rice dish was even more disappointing. When a dish categorized as a "Special" is as poorly executed as this one was, I know I'm not going to take a chance on coming back and trying something else. Everything about the dish was poorly executed: cold pieces of steamed chicken you could tell weren't fresh and Chinese sausage carelessly sprinkled over a bed of room temperature sticky rice. I've eaten at so many Vietnamese restaurants, and I have never been somewhere where a rice dish isn't composed of at least rice, vegetables of some sort (cucumber, maybe tomato), nuoc mam sauce, and meat.

I walked away hungry and frustrated that I had spent twenty dollars on such a disappointing meal... I will not be returning again. Heed the bad reviews; sometimes ethnic restaurants will have subpar reviews despite decent food since they have poor service. This does not apply here!

excerpts: I'll certainly be back for the pho ga, and maybe the steamed chicken with rice.
steamed chicken.author: David D.
steamed chicken.review:
Finally scratched something off my to-do list and finally tried the pho ga (chichen pho) at Turtle Tower.

Decided to order the #10 Pho Ga with chicken giblets. The size large isn't that big, probably the size of a small or regular elsewhere. The broth was extremely flavorful and aromatic. The noodles were okay, could have been a bit chewier, but were nicely cooked and not stuck together. The #10 has shredded chicken meat and skin which provides texture and fattiness to an otherwise very lean dish. The chicken giblets were fantastic, although I did not care for the toughness of the kidneys (but that's just the nature of eating the kidneys). 

This pho is from northern Vietnam which means it's not served with the plum sauce, sprouts, and basil that you might be used to.  You won't miss them much, as the chicken flavor is so pure and rich. 

Apparently the place has been recently remodeled and looks quite nice inside, although they have too many tables in a cramped setting, so much so that one of the tables needed to be left empty as no more customers could squeeze in around it.

I'll certainly be back for the pho ga, and maybe the steamed chicken with rice. 

Pro Tip: Please don't put your chili sauce / sriracha directly into the broth. You're disrupting a balance in flavor that took hours to achieve. Put your chili sauce into the small saucer provided, and use as needed!

excerpts: We also tried the fresh SPRING ROLLS, which were OK, but I'd opt for a side of the DIA GA LUOC (steamed chicken with bones) or something related to their very clean and enjoyable broth.
steamed chicken.author: Patrick M.
steamed chicken.review:
4 for food. 3 for service. 3 for atmosphere. 

Turtle Tower is a great place if you want consistency and a homey meal. 

This was my first time eating real Pho in SF. It is North Vietnamese style pho. I had the well mentioned PHO GA (chicken) which was very clean and well seasoned. Chicken in the PHO GA was ok and same with the noodles (they get a little mushy toward the end). I'm usually sensitive to very salty things (I feel my eyes get puffy) and I ate the entire bowl and did not get that feeling. 

No need for hoisen sauce (nor is there any). If you like the kick just dip your noodles in the red chili sauce from time to time. 

We also tried the fresh SPRING ROLLS, which were OK, but I'd opt for a side of the DIA GA LUOC (steamed chicken with bones) or something related to their very clean and enjoyable broth.

excerpts: Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo).
There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
steamed chicken.author: Ed U.
steamed chicken.review:
It's the tale of two Turtle Towers. It's the best of pho, it's the worst of pho. How can two Turtle Towers be this different in execution and still have the same menu? It's kinda when Patty Duke played identical twin cousins who were total opposites, then they played each other to fool others and knee-slapping hilarity ensues. No hilarity to be found here. Just a standard Vietnamese place in a location that isn't the most pedestrian-friendly at the relatively barren corner of 6th and Bryant. It feels downright suburban compared to the more densely populated Little Saigon location (see my review - http://www.yelp.com/biz/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:idtbVotN081VoyQb9aXurw). 

I ordered the same thing I order at the other location. Jamie W. and I shared the $4.95 Goi Cuon (Spring Rolls), which are impossible to fail with fresh prawns and basil leaves peeking through the near-transparent rice paper. It comes with with addictive peanut dipping sauce (see photo). We both ordered the same entree, the large $7.95 bowl of Pho Bo Dac Biet, which has strips of rare beef, tripe, flank and brisket (see photo). This is where it went wrong - the broth didn't taste right like it was watered down considerably. Pho with only marginally satisfying broth just shouldn't exist. That's when pho should be spelled with an 'F'. 

Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo). There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible. When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it. There's no saving it. Bummer. Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here. The rainbow blend is a plus, but it's too bad that they're coming to a place where the food can be subpar. 

FOOD - 3 stars...darn disappointing compared to the original Turtle Tower in Little Saigon, especially the pho broth 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...feels like a mall court place 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...appeared more focused on turnover 
TOTAL - 3 stars...worth strolling to the Tenderloin to get something more flavorful than what they have here

excerpts: What really turned me off from this particular location was the time I ordered their steamed chicken (without rice) to go for $8
I opened the container to take a peek at my food before leaving the restaurant because my order felt really light.
steamed chicken.author: Catherine C.
steamed chicken.review:
THIS PLACE SUCKS. I have no idea why people love Turtle Tower's chicken pho so much, it's utterly bland and tasteless. 

What really turned me off from this particular location was the time I ordered their steamed chicken (without rice) to go for $8+. I opened the container to take a peek at my food before leaving the restaurant because my order felt really light. Turns out I got less than a chicken leg. Most of the "meat" I got was skin and bones. The waiters there were extremely rude when I raised the issue. The debate got kind of heated my friend asked the waiter if he would have paid $8 for the pathetic chicken platter I got, and he retorted, "Well, I wouldn't have ordered that dish." Total BS. In the end, I just asked for my money back and left feeling pissed.

excerpts: Steamed chicken w/ bone $8.20 small
- it was ok, nothing special.
steamed chicken.author: Ann L.
steamed chicken.review:
Went to this location of Turtle Tower Restaurant, 6th & Bryant, because of the Scoutmob deal.  It's a long walk from Civic Center Bart so I don't recommend walking.  Better to drive.

Wait was maybe 1hr, I don't know.  Very long.  We still put our name on the list.

FREE Small pho ga chicken noodle soup (reg $6.20).  I loved it.  B. not so much, he doesn't like their noodles, but I did.

Giu Cuon Spring rolls $5.15 - 2 rolls cut up w/ mint, shrimp, pork, fresh rice paper, peanut sauce on the side. Tasted ok.

I wanted Banh Cuon - it's hard to find everywhere, so was looking forward to it.  Sold out when I went.  So sad.

Steamed chicken w/ bone $8.20 small - it was ok, nothing special.  Lemon/salty dipping sauce on the side.

Iced condensed milk Vietnamese coffee $3.20 - That's pricey for Vietnamese iced coffee.  Tasted ok.

Our total about $18 before tip.  They take credit card.  One unisex bathroom in the back.

Closed Sun
M-Sat 10-9

Website:
www.turtletowersf.com

excerpts: I wanted to try their probably-famous-pho, but it was such a hot day, I decided to opt for grilled pork over steamed rice ($7.75).
The pork is the most important meal of the plate, and it was dry.
I was quite disappointed.
Their sauce for the dish didn't make it any better as expected.
Their guava juice however comes in a can and honestly, I felt like that was the best thing I had.
Don't get the grilled pork!!
Also, they only accept cash here.
grilled pork over steamed rice.author: Mandy G.
grilled pork over steamed rice.review:
I gave it 3 stars because the food was meh, but the service was good. Perhaps it's because I didn't order the right thing..

I've heard good things about Turtle Tower, but never really wanted to drive out to downtown for it. Being in the area due to jury duty, I decided to give it a shot instead of sleeping in my hot car during lunch..

Service was good, but the dish I ordered wasn't so great. Their menu for this location didn't have much options, as compared to the one I am seeing online at the moment. I wanted to try their probably-famous-pho, but it was such a hot day, I decided to opt for grilled pork over steamed rice ($7.75). The pork is the most important meal of the plate, and it was dry. I was quite disappointed. Their sauce for the dish didn't make it any better as expected. Their guava juice however comes in a can and honestly, I felt like that was the best thing I had. I should've given this place another chance, but it's been so hot lately, so maybe in the winter. 

Just a warning to all, try their probably-famous-pho! Don't get the grilled pork!! Also, they only accept cash here.

excerpts: Also I got a banh mi to go (pate, ham, & pork).
It's really dry and short in length, not worth the $5 price.
You're better off finding a a good sandwich in the TL.
pate.author: Kevin S.
pate.review:
Ordered the large #2 Pho Tai Rare Beef Pho this time, and it was just as delicious. The way they make their rare beef is prepped almost like a beef burger patty but easier to rip off with each bite. Wished there was more meat though. The soup has slightly more sodium than the #9 Chicken Pho, but it's still not too salty for a soup broth. I can't say if the #2 or the #9 is better since they're in their own categories, but with either dish, you really can't go wrong.

Also I got a banh mi to go (pate, ham, & pork). It's really dry and short in length, not worth the $5 price. You're better off finding a a good sandwich in the TL.

excerpts: We have been back just to give them another chance, but they consistently run out of pate for their banh mi.
pate.author: Alice C.
pate.review:
~*~*~ 1200th review! ~*~*~

It is disappointing, really. I went to the original Turtle Tower location and really enjoyed their chicken pho, so I tried to rally my coworkers to come over here. 

The noodles were too soft, like the food was soaking in the broth for a while before they delivered it to our table - which made sense because we waited forrrrreverrrrrr for our food.

At the end of our meal, we were told their POS system stopped working. Their ATM didn't work either. Seemed like they had a network issue. We had to run to some place across the street to get cash. It was quite annoying that the staff didn't mention anything and they weren't very helpful either.

We have been back just to give them another chance, but they consistently run out of pate for their banh mi. We have never seen it in stock, which is quite a shame - if they don't have it, just don't put it on the menu.

I guess this location is a no go. I hope the other one I like hasn't gone downhill as well.

excerpts: I also got a sandwich of pork, pate and fried egg.
You get to choose three items.
My sandwich was awesome and it bums me out that the Turtle Tower on Geary doesn't serve the sandwiches.
Oh wells.
At least I know I can get my fill here on 6th Street.
I'm so glad they opened one here where I can get dinner on my way home.
pate.author: Jen L.
pate.review: Love me some North Vietnamese cuisine! We saw an open parking spot on a rainy night and decided to run in with the kiddo. They quickly saw that we had a car seat and sat us in the corner to give us space to tuck him away. The service here is really fast and extremely friendly. You get in, order, eat and pay. I typically get #5 (stir-fried beef with celery, carrot, onion, and leek noodle soup) and my husband loves their #6 which is almost the same as #5 but the noodles are pan fried. He likes the smokey flavor but I find it a tad too oily for my liking. It doesn't really matter though because both are really delicious. In fact, all of their soup noodles are wonderful and great on a rainy day. I also got a sandwich of pork, pate and fried egg. You get to choose three items. My sandwich was awesome and it bums me out that the Turtle Tower on Geary doesn't serve the sandwiches. Oh wells. At least I know I can get my fill here on 6th Street. I'm so glad they opened one here where I can get dinner on my way home.

excerpts: The banh mi (price yet to be determined) includes the standard butter, mayo, cilantro, carrots & jalapenos, then pick your choice of 3 proteins: pate, ham, sausage, fried egg, chicken, and pork.
pate.author: Luis C.
pate.review:
Location #3 for Turtle Tower is open for business! (including weekends) http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q#XyE2ArO33JSt29m8FdVF5Q The official grand opening is next week Wed. June 1st, 2011.

5 stars seem like a high rating, but there aren't many worthwhile eateries in the area (near Hall of Justice), and the staff are super friendly. So they get extra points for all that. Like most TT fans, my favorite is the Pho Ga.

Those stuck on jury duty will love this addition. I know that they already can get Vietnamese food from Grab N Go across the street, but in my opinion TT's food is way better.

The space is smaller than the branch on Larkin street. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA#4tmpNXJCPcq3MWQQOyokrA During this soft opening week they feature a limited menu, but the best news is that they told me that they'll start making custom made banh mi on the grand opening day. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco-3?select=qPxHdydcJr9tM9QTa4xC_w#cw_9kbK5kfy_PJj88t3X1Q Note: don't expect it to be as cheap as Saigon sandos.

The banh mi (price yet to be determined) includes the standard butter, mayo, cilantro, carrots & jalapenos, then pick your choice of 3 proteins: pate, ham, sausage, fried egg, chicken, and pork. One of the few to offer a fried egg option, others are Bun Mee, Little Green Cyclo food truck, and Banh Mi Ba Le in Oakland.

Most prices are similar to the Larkin location, including the imperial rolls for $2.15 each (ouch!). Except that most Pho (small $6.20-$7.20, large $7.20-$8.20) and entrees costs about 25 cents more here. Not by much, so I think it's okay.

I'm concerned that this area has no foot traffic on weekends. Except for a few places like McDonald's, most eateries are open weekdays for lunch only. So I don't think it's wise for TT to have weekends hours. A soup business is different from other eateries. The stove remains on for long hours to keep the soup hot, so their utilities bill is high even when they have no customers.

I'd like TT to remain in business, so they need to make some wise decisions from the beginning. Otherwise they'll suffer the same fate as all the previous tenants that went out of business at this corner.

Hours: daily 9am-9pm (revised 2013)

** Update 2013: In case u ever found this shop closed, when u thought it was open. Here's a brief synopsis of the schedule changes. Initial operating hours were 7am-5pm, later extended to 9pm, with a break between lunch and dinner service. Later it changed to continuous service, to match their other locations. Then on January 2013, the schedule was cut to Mon-Sat 10am-4pm, closed Sundays. And in March 2013 they changed their minds again, so it's back to 9pm, including weekends.

excerpts: You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg.
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
The pate was kind of weird tasting.
Fried egg was awesome though.
The bread was a softer, more buttery kind.
pate.author: Sherry L.
pate.review:
I really enjoy the pho ga at Turtle Tower. But this time I went to the SOMA one for the bahn mi. What can I say, I love banh mi more than pho. I was pretty disappointed with the banh mi, unfortunately. You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg. I asked what happens if I only choose one filling, and the guy said I'll just get more of the one filling.

I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg. I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before. When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was. What happened to more meat? The pate was kind of weird tasting. Fried egg was awesome though. The bread was a softer, more buttery kind. But I think I like the crustier baguette better.

I think I'll stick to the pho ga at Turtle Tower and get my banh mi elsewhere.

EDIT 5/21/2013: Pho Ga = tons of MSG. Avoid!

excerpts: $4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage.
As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich.
It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price.
This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70.
Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong.
Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets".
Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines.
A small is $3 and a large is $5.
pate.author: Dan B.
pate.review:
Tonight the muuusic seeems so loud!
I wish that! we! could! looose this crowd!
May-be! it's beeetter this wayyy.
We'd hurt each oth-er with the things we want to saaay.
We could have been so gooood togethah,
We could have lived this daannce forevah,
But nowwwww who's goonnnnna daance with meeee?
Pleeeease staaayy!

...And that was upon only having stepped inside the door.

$4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage. I didn't ask, but I figure you can choose the same item for all 3 or do two-and-one if you want.

Note that the sandwich will be JUST the bread and whichever item(s) you select. If you want things that come standard on other restaurants' Vietnamese sandwiches, e.g., mayo, shredded carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, butter, etc., these can be added for $1.55 each.

Yes, each. As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich. It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price. This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70. Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong. #justsayin

Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets". Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines. A small is $3 and a large is $5. I'm definitely returning at some point to investigate.

ICED TEA: I watched the worker make this. It was a glass filled with 3/4 water then topped off with tea. I'm not talking about a glass of water into which were placed tea bags - this was already-brewed tea added to water. I could still taste the tea, but I thought the watering down aspect was odd.

The worker told me this location opened last year. So I'm guessing the 2007 and 2007-2008 ratings plaques on the wall were for the other locations. Also, there was a Scout Mob deal posted at the register, but I didn't read it.

You know I was,
I was wondering, you know, if
if you could keep on, because
the force, it, it's got a lot of power, and
it make me feel like um
it, it make me feel like uh...
WWOOOOOOO!!!

3 1/2 stars.

excerpts: I got the vietnamese sandwich with pate, grilled chicken, and fried egg.
pate.author: Mandy D.
pate.review:
Why, why do you disappoint me so. I got the vietnamese sandwich with pate, grilled chicken, and fried egg. I was hoping for the fried egg to be oozing out, but it's cooked well, more like a scramble.

I'm sticking to Grab-N-Go down the block for my vietnamese sandwiches.

excerpts: I also had a bite of my friends vietnamese sandwich -- good solid sandwich: meat, pickled vegetables, pate, butter sauce, on a big crispey crunchy roll.
pate.author: Christine B.
pate.review:
beef pho - it was a toss up between the beef and the chicken, but i'm always more partial to beef pho. I got a 'small' bowl which is essentially more than enough for a person. It came steaming hot with broth, a good healthy portion of meat and noodles. You really get the pungent taste of the beef broth and the meat is pretty tender and ready to melt into your mouth. 

I do have to warn you though, the pho is a bit more like the northern hanoi style so you won't get hoisin sauce or the bean sprouts. I know everyone complains about this, but give this type of pho a chance!  The only things they give you to add into your pho are jalopenos, lemon and fish sauce. 

Some other highlights are the 'che' aka vietnamese dessert - my favorite is the 3 colors one " che ba mau" -- green pandan pudding/jello, sweet beans, cocconut milk ice, and more asian jellos. DELICIOUS! 

I also had a bite of my friends vietnamese sandwich -- good solid sandwich: meat, pickled vegetables, pate, butter sauce, on a big crispey crunchy roll.

excerpts: Turtle Tower offers banh mi with butter, mayo, veggies and a choice of 3 items: pate, jambon, sausage, grilled chicken, grilled pork, and a fried egg.
But how can you offer pate and jambon for banh mi if you don't have cha lua??!!?!
It's a disgrace to the banh
mi.
Btw, if you want to pay an additional $3.50 for extra chicken for your pho ga, you should know that it comes on a small condiment dish.
I also don't like how the banh mi comes in a basket.
pate.author: Peggy N.
pate.review:
I had such high hopes for this place due to the 4.5 stars my fellow yelpers gave.  Unfortunately, my hopes were all shattered.  

The wait was excruciating.  With a long list on their whiteboard, I would think they would make every effort to turn their tables quickly.  I hate getting my check before I ask for it in a nice high end restaurant - but at a casual joint like Turtle Tower, they should be dropping those checks on the table as soon as the customer takes that last bite of banh mi or swallows that final spoonful of soup.  Not to say that they need to rush their customers but sometimes, a nudge in the right direction is just what you need.  Better for revenue, better for tips, and better for the people waiting in line.

The staff seemed confused.  If you ask for a simple change in one of their menu items, they have to check with the boss first.  That is something you can prep your staff on beforehand.  I noticed one customer ordered a small bowl of noodles, received a big bowl, was charged for the big bowl, and when he questioned it on his bill, the server looked doubtful and asked another server for help.  I thought they would adjust his bill and only charge him for a small bowl but they didn't.  That doesn't seem like a smart business decision.

The banh mi is weird and not exactly authentic.  I'm not normally concerned about the cultural authenticity of my food - as long as it tastes good.  Turtle Tower offers banh mi with butter, mayo, veggies and a choice of 3 items: pate, jambon, sausage, grilled chicken, grilled pork, and a fried egg.  But how can you offer pate and jambon for banh mi if you don't have cha lua??!!?!  It's a disgrace to the banh mi.  I'm not even going to discuss the randomness of having a sausage and fried egg option.  

Btw, if you want to pay an additional $3.50 for extra chicken for your pho ga, you should know that it comes on a small condiment dish.  I also don't like how the banh mi comes in a basket.  Considering how it's a sit down lunch, shouldn't my food at least come on a regular plate?

I give it one star, partly because yelp is making me do it, partly because they pour their water out of a Brita pitcher, partly because the disposable chopsticks are the good kind.

excerpts: Not the best I've ever had, but the bread was fresh, the pate, pork, and ham were all flavorful.
THe carrots and cucumbers added great texture, but no daikon radish.
I see a lot of potential in this place.
With this location being so close to me, I'll definitely be back when they are ready with the full menu.
pate.author: Siao W.
pate.review:
I've always wondered if having to fight off crackheads is what makes the pho at the Larkin Turtle Tower so delicious. To answer this question, I tried this new Turtle Tower in SOMA. I found that without crackheads on the street, the pho is JUST as delicious.
     This week was the grand opening, so they only offered a limited menu. However, their famous chicken pho was on par with their other locations. The place nice and clean. There was no sticky floors or sticky tables.
     In the absence of crackheads, this location offers something the Larkin location doesn't...Bahn mi. Not the best I've ever had, but the bread was fresh, the pate, pork, and ham were all flavorful. THe carrots and cucumbers added great texture, but no daikon radish.
     I see a lot of potential in this place. With this location being so close to me, I'll definitely be back when they are ready with the full menu.

excerpts: Randomly being in the neighborhood, I dropped in to this new location and grabbed the pho ga, which many say is the definitive dish at Turtle Tower, and a banh mi with pate, fried egg, and grilled chicken.
The service was a bit slow considering how empty the restaurant was at 11AM on a weekday, but the food arrived in honestly under a minute
so I wasn't mad about it.
So...about that pho ga.
I'll be blunt: it wasn't the dish that was sold to me.
Sure, the broth was balanced and the noodles were supple and well-cooked, but everything was just average.
I wasn't blown away.
The pho ga is good for a quick bite and a warm dish on a cold SF night, but that's about it.
As for the banh mi, it was generously loaded with the meats and eggs, but almost too generously loaded.
The pickled vegetables and cilantro were really afterthoughts in this sandwich, causing it to be very heavy and laden with fat.
pate.author: Frank Y.
pate.review:
Turtle Tower: Hype machine?

Whenever I asked my Vietnamese friends about pho, my left ear would be falling off from the barrage of praise for Turtle Tower. I've always been skeptical, though. I've been more of a Kevin's Noodle House kind of guy, like as in the "I've gone to Kevin's since middle school" kind of guy. Was Turtle Tower worth the trip?

Randomly being in the neighborhood, I dropped in to this new location and grabbed the pho ga, which many say is the definitive dish at Turtle Tower, and a banh mi with pate, fried egg, and grilled chicken. The service was a bit slow considering how empty the restaurant was at 11AM on a weekday, but the food arrived in honestly under a minute so I wasn't mad about it. So...about that pho ga. I'll be blunt: it wasn't the dish that was sold to me. Sure, the broth was balanced and the noodles were supple and well-cooked, but everything was just average. I wasn't blown away. The pho ga is good for a quick bite and a warm dish on a cold SF night, but that's about it. As for the banh mi, it was generously loaded with the meats and eggs, but almost too generously loaded. The pickled vegetables and cilantro were really afterthoughts in this sandwich, causing it to be very heavy and laden with fat. Sure, the banh mi was good, but I could barely stomach a half before calling it quits.

All in all, Turtle Tower was just another dining experience, nothing noted positively or negatively. It was just a forgettable meal, for better or worse.

excerpts:
Fried imperial roll - 2/5
Grilled pork - 2/5

Overall, "A-OK" for chicken noodle soup.
grilled pork.author: Mark O.
grilled pork.review:
Dinner review. 

Chicken noodle soup - 3/5 - 7x7. 
Stewed beef in wine sauce - 2/5
Fried imperial roll - 2/5
Grilled pork - 2/5

Overall, "A-OK" for chicken noodle soup.

excerpts: I wanted to try their probably-famous-pho, but it was such a hot day, I decided to opt for grilled pork over steamed rice ($7.75).
The pork is the most important meal of the plate, and it was dry.
I was quite disappointed.
Their sauce for the dish didn't make it any better as expected.
Their guava juice however comes in a can and honestly, I felt like that was the best thing I had.
Don't get the grilled pork!!
Also, they only accept cash here.
grilled pork.author: Mandy G.
grilled pork.review:
I gave it 3 stars because the food was meh, but the service was good. Perhaps it's because I didn't order the right thing..

I've heard good things about Turtle Tower, but never really wanted to drive out to downtown for it. Being in the area due to jury duty, I decided to give it a shot instead of sleeping in my hot car during lunch..

Service was good, but the dish I ordered wasn't so great. Their menu for this location didn't have much options, as compared to the one I am seeing online at the moment. I wanted to try their probably-famous-pho, but it was such a hot day, I decided to opt for grilled pork over steamed rice ($7.75). The pork is the most important meal of the plate, and it was dry. I was quite disappointed. Their sauce for the dish didn't make it any better as expected. Their guava juice however comes in a can and honestly, I felt like that was the best thing I had. I should've given this place another chance, but it's been so hot lately, so maybe in the winter. 

Just a warning to all, try their probably-famous-pho! Don't get the grilled pork!! Also, they only accept cash here.

excerpts: At the Turtle, they use a succulent grilled pork which makes the goi cuon so much more flavorful.
grilled pork.author: Erin G.
grilled pork.review:
What I ate: Goi cuon, pho ga, chrysanthemum tea
Visit date: May 30, 2012
First time? Yes.

Ok, so it's not in the best part of town, but if you're craving some stellar goi cuon, Turtle Tower is the place. I normally get my goi cuon with just shrimp -- the pork just never cut it for me. I forgot to say 'just shrimp' here, but no worries. At the Turtle, they use a succulent grilled pork which makes the goi cuon so much more flavorful. Their sauce was finger-lickin', too -- not too thick and not too runny.

Now, what brought me here was Scoutmob's (Am I allowed to name drop like that?) free pho ga deal. The pho ga was subpar. Sure, the broth was good (not the best, though), but the chicken was chewy. Not ok. And, they keep the skin on the chicken. Maybe that's good for flavoring, but I don't like eating it. 

After soup, I wanted something cold (ice cold!). I had the chrysanthemum tea (from a can) and asked for ice so the sweetness could be diluted (you know me and not liking super sweet drinks). This was a perfect way to end a meal.

Staff is friendly, and they have fancy bag hooks under each table. Plus!

excerpts: You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg.
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg.
I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before.
When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was.
What happened to more meat?
The pate was kind of weird tasting.
Fried egg was awesome though.
The bread was a softer, more buttery kind.
grilled pork.author: Sherry L.
grilled pork.review:
I really enjoy the pho ga at Turtle Tower. But this time I went to the SOMA one for the bahn mi. What can I say, I love banh mi more than pho. I was pretty disappointed with the banh mi, unfortunately. You can choose up to 3 fillings for your sandwich, from the following choices: grilled pork, grilled chicken, sausage, pate, ham, fried egg. I asked what happens if I only choose one filling, and the guy said I'll just get more of the one filling.

I ended up getting two banh mi's, one with grilled pork, and one with pate, ham, and fried egg. I was very excited, because I've never seen fried egg as a filling before. When I opened the pork banh mi, I was surprised to see how little filling there was. What happened to more meat? The pate was kind of weird tasting. Fried egg was awesome though. The bread was a softer, more buttery kind. But I think I like the crustier baguette better.

I think I'll stick to the pho ga at Turtle Tower and get my banh mi elsewhere.

EDIT 5/21/2013: Pho Ga = tons of MSG. Avoid!

excerpts: $4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage.
As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich.
It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price.
This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70.
Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong.
Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets".
Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines.
A small is $3 and a large is $5.
grilled pork.author: Dan B.
grilled pork.review:
Tonight the muuusic seeems so loud!
I wish that! we! could! looose this crowd!
May-be! it's beeetter this wayyy.
We'd hurt each oth-er with the things we want to saaay.
We could have been so gooood togethah,
We could have lived this daannce forevah,
But nowwwww who's goonnnnna daance with meeee?
Pleeeease staaayy!

...And that was upon only having stepped inside the door.

$4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage. I didn't ask, but I figure you can choose the same item for all 3 or do two-and-one if you want.

Note that the sandwich will be JUST the bread and whichever item(s) you select. If you want things that come standard on other restaurants' Vietnamese sandwiches, e.g., mayo, shredded carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, butter, etc., these can be added for $1.55 each.

Yes, each. As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich. It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price. This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70. Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong. #justsayin

Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets". Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines. A small is $3 and a large is $5. I'm definitely returning at some point to investigate.

ICED TEA: I watched the worker make this. It was a glass filled with 3/4 water then topped off with tea. I'm not talking about a glass of water into which were placed tea bags - this was already-brewed tea added to water. I could still taste the tea, but I thought the watering down aspect was odd.

The worker told me this location opened last year. So I'm guessing the 2007 and 2007-2008 ratings plaques on the wall were for the other locations. Also, there was a Scout Mob deal posted at the register, but I didn't read it.

You know I was,
I was wondering, you know, if
if you could keep on, because
the force, it, it's got a lot of power, and
it make me feel like um
it, it make me feel like uh...
WWOOOOOOO!!!

3 1/2 stars.

excerpts: Grilled pork appetizer - the pork flavor isn't really good, and it was grilled for far too long.
grilled pork.author: Mark D.
grilled pork.review:
Grilled pork appetizer - the pork flavor isn't really good, and it was grilled for far too long. Stay away from this.

Imperial rolls - this is tasty, but it's super greasy

Pho combination - their pho uses flat noodles, also only comes with jalapeño and lemon. The meat is too rare for me. Also no tendons. Broth had a funny taste. I would never come here for pho. I didn't like it at all.

excerpts: Hot day, so i ordered the Bun Cha, grilled pork and pork sausage over vermicelli.
It came on a plate.
I'm used to having this served in a bowl so you can mix the meat, vegetables, and sauce all together.
Maybe because I'm a new face, they wanted to see how I was going mix and eat without making a huge mess.
The waiter later gave me a small rice bowl, so I could mix about 2 mouthful at a time.
Very tedious, but I wasn't in a hurry.
The food was good; pork and sausage were very good and not salty.
grilled pork.author: Les T.
grilled pork.review:
First time here. Hot day, so i ordered the Bun Cha, grilled pork and pork sausage over vermicelli.  It came on a plate.  I'm used to having this served in a bowl so you can mix the meat, vegetables, and sauce all together.  Maybe because I'm a new face, they wanted to see how I was going mix and eat without making a huge mess.  The waiter later gave me a small rice bowl, so I could mix about 2 mouthful at a time. Very tedious, but I wasn't in a hurry.  The food was good; pork and sausage were very good and not salty.  Noodles were good and had a nice flavor.

Oddly, the whole place smelled like bleach.  Maybe they just finished cleaning the place before I got there.  I'll have to go back to try some of their other dishes.

excerpts: The pork and spring rolls were tasty, and the rolls included char-grilled pork along with the usual shrimp, which was an atypical but definitely welcome addition.
grilled pork.author: Selina K.
grilled pork.review:
Came here with a friend after a hike. We had the pho tai (pho with thinly sliced rare beef), fresh spring rolls, and chargrilled pork. The beef on the pho tai was melty in the mouthy delicious - probably the tastiest beef I've had in this dish (and I've eaten this probably billions of times since infancy). 

Sadly, the pho broth wasn't very flavorful or beefy and a let down, and the noodles were more Chinese style (wider and soft) - I'm not sure if that's due to the North Vietnamese influence, but I prefer the thinner, firmer pho noodles that are what I've come to know as the standard. 

The pork and spring rolls were tasty, and the rolls included char-grilled pork along with the usual shrimp, which was an atypical but definitely welcome addition. 

Not sure if I'd visit again, but tons of available parking in SOMA and no wait time were definite pluses.

excerpts: I had grilled pork over rice.
The pork was very dry and unappetizing.
We got Imperial Rolls also.
$2.15 for one roll is pretty pricey and it was pretty sad.
grilled pork.author: Gregory W.
grilled pork.review:
Not good! I had grilled pork over rice. The pork was very dry and unappetizing. We got Imperial Rolls also. $2.15 for one roll is pretty pricey and it was pretty sad. We will not be going back here.

There are a lot better Vietnamese places within several blocks.

excerpts: I've even branched out and tried the stir fried beef noodle soup (basically chow fun soup), the stir fried beef over vermicelli noodles, and the grilled pork vermicelli dish, finding all to be pretty delicious (though salty) when the mood strikes.
grilled pork.author: Krystle S.
grilled pork.review:
I'll admit it, after my first visit to the original Turtle Tower, I was not impressed. I went in expecting southern style pho and was devastated by the absence of bean sprouts, extra difficulty in picking up the thicker noodles, and...umami that accompanied all my previous pho experiences. However, after understanding that Turtle Tower serves northern style pho and learning the differences between the regional varieties I went back, tried chicken instead of beef, and became a huge fan. 

Eventually my frequent cravings for pho ga started creeping into dinnertime, so I decided to give this outpost a try.  From one unsavory part of the city to another, the pho ga seems pretty consistent to me - piping hot with a nice, clean broth that leaves me feeling fully comforted. The service has always been friendly and I like how I've never had to wait for a table when my weekday dinner or weekend lunch cravings strike. I've even branched out and tried the stir fried beef noodle soup (basically chow fun soup), the stir fried beef over vermicelli noodles, and the grilled pork vermicelli dish, finding all to be pretty delicious (though salty) when the mood strikes.

excerpts: The grilled pork in my Vermicelli dish came out cold and really hard, it was so tough, you would think I ordered jerky or something.
My friend ordered the soup and it was really bland and had no flavor, the TL location is much better.
grilled pork.author: Kristina L.
grilled pork.review:
Hmm...been a long time fan of the OG TT in TL. Decided to come here because it was: 

1. closer to me 
2. cleaner 
3. Not in the TL (no offense TL, but even though you have some grubbin' places, I hate how it smells around there)

The first time first time I came to this location, it was amazing, I was so stoked that I didn't have to brave the TL anymore. But the second time, my food and service was definitely sub-par. The grilled pork in my Vermicelli dish came out cold and really hard, it was so tough, you would think I ordered jerky or something. My friend ordered the soup and it was really bland and had no flavor, the TL location is much better. Hopefully, they are just working out their kinks in this location, I will definitely come back for another try though. 

3.5 stars (partially biased just because I love the OG TT and staff)

excerpts: So here is my review of the grilled pork chop rice plate.
(My usual choice when going out for Vietnamese).
Compared to other pork chop rice plates, this has got to be the worst I've ever had.
The dish was devoid of flavor.
Perhaps, this menu item should have been titled "pork JERKEY over rice."
Overall, this rice plate was a let down--dry and flavorless.
grilled pork.author: Matt S.
grilled pork.review:
I'm "that guy..."  The guy who goes to a Vietnamese restaurant and orders a rice plate or a vermicelli bowl instead of a bowl of hot delicious pho or noodle soup.  I guess I'm just not a big fan of noodle soup (udon, ramen, won ton noodles, etc..)

So here is my review of the grilled pork chop rice plate.  (My usual choice when going out for Vietnamese).  Compared to other pork chop rice plates, this has got to be the worst I've ever had.  The dish was devoid of flavor.  Perhaps, this menu item should have been titled "pork JERKEY over rice."  Overall, this rice plate was a let down--dry and flavorless.  I wouldn't even subject more beagle to these scraps.

The group of 6 I was with also shared 3 orders of the springs rolls.  I had a much better experience with these.  The servings were large.  We probably only needed to order 2 orders.  Each order contained 3 spring rolls, but were cut into 6 pieces.  Each piece itself could have served as a single roll!  Flavors were inline with your typical Vietnamese eatery.

Overall, I can't attest to the actual noodle soup dishes, but the rice dish that I ordered was horrible.

excerpts: Turtle Tower offers banh mi with butter, mayo, veggies and a choice of 3 items: pate, jambon, sausage, grilled chicken, grilled pork, and a fried egg.
But how can you offer pate and jambon for banh mi if you don't have cha lua??!!?!
It's a disgrace to the banh
mi.
Btw, if you want to pay an additional $3.50 for extra chicken for your pho ga, you should know that it comes on a small condiment dish.
I also don't like how the banh mi comes in a basket.
grilled pork.author: Peggy N.
grilled pork.review:
I had such high hopes for this place due to the 4.5 stars my fellow yelpers gave.  Unfortunately, my hopes were all shattered.  

The wait was excruciating.  With a long list on their whiteboard, I would think they would make every effort to turn their tables quickly.  I hate getting my check before I ask for it in a nice high end restaurant - but at a casual joint like Turtle Tower, they should be dropping those checks on the table as soon as the customer takes that last bite of banh mi or swallows that final spoonful of soup.  Not to say that they need to rush their customers but sometimes, a nudge in the right direction is just what you need.  Better for revenue, better for tips, and better for the people waiting in line.

The staff seemed confused.  If you ask for a simple change in one of their menu items, they have to check with the boss first.  That is something you can prep your staff on beforehand.  I noticed one customer ordered a small bowl of noodles, received a big bowl, was charged for the big bowl, and when he questioned it on his bill, the server looked doubtful and asked another server for help.  I thought they would adjust his bill and only charge him for a small bowl but they didn't.  That doesn't seem like a smart business decision.

The banh mi is weird and not exactly authentic.  I'm not normally concerned about the cultural authenticity of my food - as long as it tastes good.  Turtle Tower offers banh mi with butter, mayo, veggies and a choice of 3 items: pate, jambon, sausage, grilled chicken, grilled pork, and a fried egg.  But how can you offer pate and jambon for banh mi if you don't have cha lua??!!?!  It's a disgrace to the banh mi.  I'm not even going to discuss the randomness of having a sausage and fried egg option.  

Btw, if you want to pay an additional $3.50 for extra chicken for your pho ga, you should know that it comes on a small condiment dish.  I also don't like how the banh mi comes in a basket.  Considering how it's a sit down lunch, shouldn't my food at least come on a regular plate?

I give it one star, partly because yelp is making me do it, partly because they pour their water out of a Brita pitcher, partly because the disposable chopsticks are the good kind.

excerpts: I got to choose 3 meats from a list (fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork) and the sandwich came with the usual veggies and slathered with butter.
grilled pork.author: Frances N.
grilled pork.review:
:: Service, Setting ::
Just opened, so service is disorganized. 

The place is generally set-up for tables of 2 people. Went with 4 people and ended up waiting for 30min as pair after pair who walked in the door were seated minutes later.

:: Food ::
Vietnamese sandwich was DELICIOUS, and only $4.50. I got to choose 3 meats from a list (fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork) and the sandwich came with the usual veggies and slathered with butter.

Maybe it was the wait, but the sandwich was to die for.
Note: HaNoi cuisine, but I forget the veggie their menu said they don't use

excerpts: Instead of grilled pork, you get meat patties.
grilled pork.author: Tyler C.
grilled pork.review:
Turtle tower just opened up a few weeks ago, and it's pretty close to work, so I thought it would be a great new option to add to my lunch routine. But I've come here 3 times, ordering various different items each time, and I've left disappointed for the most part.  Maybe I just don't like northern style Vietnamese food.

Spring rolls - This was actually pretty good, and came with a tasty peanuty dipping sauce. My only complain was that one of the pieces of lettuce was tinged brown because it was slightly wilted.  

Beef Stew in Wine Sauce - The flavor is ok, but it's sooo salty. 

Vermicelli - It's Northern style, so it's not mixed for you.  Instead of grilled pork, you get meat patties.  And there isn't as much of a mix of veggies.  

Combination Beef Pho - The broth wasn't as flavorful as I had hoped.  Also, the beef I got looked like  it had been grounded and it didn't taste very good.  It was still pink after soaking in the pho, which was warm rather than hot.  I didn't finish my dish because I didn't like it very much.

And the final note is that the prices here are kinda high for Vietnamese food.  You can get similar or better quality Vietnamese food for much cheaper in SF.  Just go to Sunset or Tenderloin.

excerpts: The grilled pork noodles dip 'bun cha', chicken pho 'pho ga', rice silk crepe with ground pork and mushroom 'banh cuon' and 'pho ap chao' are really done in the Hanoian way (my hometown).
grilled pork.author: Anh N.
grilled pork.review: Like a hidden gem. The grilled pork noodles dip 'bun cha', chicken pho 'pho ga', rice silk crepe with ground pork and mushroom 'banh cuon' and 'pho ap chao' are really done in the Hanoian way (my hometown).

excerpts: I ordered the #19 - grilled pork with rice.
The pork was tough, chewy and dry.
The grilled pork was not grilled, it was microwaved.
Better off with my frozen Stouffer dinner.
grilled pork.author: susan g.
grilled pork.review: I ordered the #19 - grilled pork with rice.  The pork was tough, chewy and dry.  The grilled pork was not grilled, it was microwaved.  Better off with my frozen Stouffer dinner.

excerpts: I had the grilled pork with steamed rice and it was not what I expected.
There wasn't enough meat nor veggies
(there was a lettuce leaf and maybe one slice of tomato).
The fish sauce also tasted strange to me..
I guess I'm used to the garlic/chili packed fish sauce.
I've tried so many different Vietnamese restaurants and different Com Thit Nuongs in my life (in LA and SD particularly) and this place was not up to par.
grilled pork.author: Lynnie T.
grilled pork.review: After hearing the good and the bad, I decided to try Turtle Tower.  Unfortunately, I'm not too crazy about it.  I had the grilled pork with steamed rice and it was not what I expected.  There wasn't enough meat nor veggies (there was a lettuce leaf and maybe one slice of tomato).  The fish sauce also tasted strange to me.. I guess I'm used to the garlic/chili packed fish sauce.  I've tried so many different Vietnamese restaurants and different Com Thit Nuongs in my life (in LA and SD particularly) and this place was not up to par.

excerpts: Tu Lan up 6th street and Market charges $7 for a bowl containing both a more substantial portion of grilled pork and one huge spring roll.

We were disappointed to see one of the cooks reheat the pork in a microwave, and we were even more disappointed when the food finally arrived to our table: overcooked rice noodles, off-putting sauce...
It was honestly the worse vermicelli bowls we had ever had.
I don't know how the rest of the food on the menu is, but unfortunately for Turtle Tower, we'll keep going to Tu Lan for our vermicelli bowl fixes, even if it means walking up 4-5 blocks!
grilled pork.author: Remy L.
grilled pork.review: We were very excited to see a new Vietnamese restaurant opening right across from our building. We tried it today. Unfortunately, it will be the last time. We ordered the vermicelli bowl with pork and the vermicelli bowl with spring rolls, our staple order. Portions of meat and spring rolls were small for the price ($8-something). Tu Lan up 6th street and Market charges $7 for a bowl containing both a more substantial portion of grilled pork and one huge spring roll. We were disappointed to see one of the cooks reheat the pork in a microwave, and we were even more disappointed when the food finally arrived to our table: overcooked rice noodles, off-putting sauce...It was honestly the worse vermicelli bowls we had ever had. I don't know how the rest of the food on the menu is, but unfortunately for Turtle Tower, we'll keep going to Tu Lan for our vermicelli bowl fixes, even if it means walking up 4-5 blocks!

excerpts: Basically, my sandwich included cucumber, carrots, and grilled pork on an ordinary bun (nothing like a baguette) and a lot of unwanted jalapenos.
I ask the girl taking the order how you can eat a sandwich without any spread or sauce in it
and she says the sandwiches are not like anywhere else
and they don't put anything in it.
Really?
I'd be okay if the grilled pork was dripping with sauce to help coat the bread, but it was dried as well.
WTF!
I think they should just stick to the pho which they are will known for and stay clear of sandwiches and everything else.
Should have learned my lesson the first time I came here when they first opened and failed miserably at their take on dinner menus.
grilled pork.author: Matt V.
grilled pork.review: I don't recommend coming here for any sandwich. They do not know how to make a proper sandwich. I ordered a few pork sandwiches without jalepenos and ended up getting sandwiches with lots of jalapenos. Basically, my sandwich included cucumber, carrots, and grilled pork on an ordinary bun (nothing like a baguette) and a lot of unwanted jalapenos. I ask the girl taking the order how you can eat a sandwich without any spread or sauce in it and she says the sandwiches are not like anywhere else and they don't put anything in it. Really? I'd be okay if the grilled pork was dripping with sauce to help coat the bread, but it was dried as well. WTF! I think they should just stick to the pho which they are will known for and stay clear of sandwiches and everything else. Should have learned my lesson the first time I came here when they first opened and failed miserably at their take on dinner menus.

excerpts: The chao ga (chicken porridge) is absolutely awful.
Absolutely no taste, and the rice seemed like 5 days old stale.
But when I told the waiter, he was like ok, and allowed me to order a chicken pho, my usual.
Lol I vow to never venture out of my turtle tower chicken pho obsession!
chicken porridge.author: Annie K.
chicken porridge.review:
The chao ga (chicken porridge) is absolutely awful. Absolutely no taste, and the rice seemed like 5 days old stale. But when I told the waiter, he was like ok, and allowed me to order a chicken pho, my usual. Lol I vow to never venture out of my turtle tower chicken pho obsession!

Tried the imperial rolls too! Very delicious!!! Also the #1 with the beef brisket was amazing too. Still will come back again and again

excerpts: The Chao Ga (Chicken Porridge) wavers at 3stars...
Its on the thicker side than what I'm used to, and the chicken was kinda dried out and bland.... definitely not as good as what my mom makes at home, but it will do.
chicken porridge.author: Lana N.
chicken porridge.review:
Stick to their tried and true and you won't leave too disappointed.

Stumbled in on New Years Day and was promptly seated and fed. Thank you Asian joints for always being reliably open on any holiday! We went with not Pho for some reason... I guess we were feeling adventurous this new year, and it was a mixture of hit and miss. 

The Spring Rolls are solid 3stars... I'd get them again if ever in the mood.

The Chao Ga (Chicken Porridge) wavers at 3stars... Its on the thicker side than what I'm used to, and the chicken was kinda dried out and bland.... definitely not as good as what my mom makes at home, but it will do.

The Beef Stew in Red Wine Sauce??... I've never seen anything like it. We were thinking it was going to be more like Bo Ca Ri (Beef Stew Curry)... but it was beef stew in a strange artificial looking red wine sauce that tasted purely like corn starch - eeck, pass!

From my experience, I'd say the Tenderloin location is probably better, but for being conveniently located down the street for our lazy asses... this place is a-okay.  Just remember that it is cash only like all other Asian hole-in-the-walls.

excerpts: Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo).
There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it.
There's
no saving it.
Bummer.
Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here.
plate of steamed chicken.author: Ed U.
plate of steamed chicken.review:
It's the tale of two Turtle Towers. It's the best of pho, it's the worst of pho. How can two Turtle Towers be this different in execution and still have the same menu? It's kinda when Patty Duke played identical twin cousins who were total opposites, then they played each other to fool others and knee-slapping hilarity ensues. No hilarity to be found here. Just a standard Vietnamese place in a location that isn't the most pedestrian-friendly at the relatively barren corner of 6th and Bryant. It feels downright suburban compared to the more densely populated Little Saigon location (see my review - http://www.yelp.com/biz/turtle-tower-restaurant-san-francisco#hrid:idtbVotN081VoyQb9aXurw). 

I ordered the same thing I order at the other location. Jamie W. and I shared the $4.95 Goi Cuon (Spring Rolls), which are impossible to fail with fresh prawns and basil leaves peeking through the near-transparent rice paper. It comes with with addictive peanut dipping sauce (see photo). We both ordered the same entree, the large $7.95 bowl of Pho Bo Dac Biet, which has strips of rare beef, tripe, flank and brisket (see photo). This is where it went wrong - the broth didn't taste right like it was watered down considerably. Pho with only marginally satisfying broth just shouldn't exist. That's when pho should be spelled with an 'F'. 

Another disappointment was the $7.05 Ga Luoc, a small plate of steamed chicken served with a ginger dipping sauce (see photo). There was an unwanted gamey (...or should I say farmy) flavor that made it almost inedible. When a dish as high-risk as steamed chicken tastes not quite right, you just stop eating it. There's no saving it. Bummer. Customers here are more of a melting pot with not only Asian families but lots of mechanics from the nearby car dealers eating lunch here. The rainbow blend is a plus, but it's too bad that they're coming to a place where the food can be subpar. 

FOOD - 3 stars...darn disappointing compared to the original Turtle Tower in Little Saigon, especially the pho broth 
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...feels like a mall court place 
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...appeared more focused on turnover 
TOTAL - 3 stars...worth strolling to the Tenderloin to get something more flavorful than what they have here

excerpts: The broth is super light and refreshing, the rice noodles are surprisingly chewy, and they give a decent amount of chicken giblets (also add the lime and jalapeños that they give you on the side into your pho!
they give another dimension to the broth).
chicken giblets.author: Alice C.
chicken giblets.review: Their Chicken Pho Ga is amazing! The broth is super light and refreshing, the rice noodles are surprisingly chewy, and they give a decent amount of chicken giblets (also add the lime and jalapeños that they give you on the side into your pho! they give another dimension to the broth).

excerpts: Decided to order the #10 Pho Ga with chicken giblets.
The size large isn't that big, probably the size of a small or regular elsewhere.
The broth was extremely flavorful and aromatic.
The noodles were okay, could have been a bit chewier, but were nicely cooked and not stuck together.
The #10 has shredded chicken meat and skin which provides texture and fattiness to an otherwise very lean dish.
The chicken giblets were fantastic, although I did not care for the toughness of the kidneys (but that's just the nature of eating the kidneys).

You won't miss them much, as the chicken flavor is so pure and rich.
I'll certainly be back for the pho ga, and maybe the steamed chicken with rice.
chicken giblets.author: David D.
chicken giblets.review:
Finally scratched something off my to-do list and finally tried the pho ga (chichen pho) at Turtle Tower.

Decided to order the #10 Pho Ga with chicken giblets. The size large isn't that big, probably the size of a small or regular elsewhere. The broth was extremely flavorful and aromatic. The noodles were okay, could have been a bit chewier, but were nicely cooked and not stuck together. The #10 has shredded chicken meat and skin which provides texture and fattiness to an otherwise very lean dish. The chicken giblets were fantastic, although I did not care for the toughness of the kidneys (but that's just the nature of eating the kidneys). 

This pho is from northern Vietnam which means it's not served with the plum sauce, sprouts, and basil that you might be used to.  You won't miss them much, as the chicken flavor is so pure and rich. 

Apparently the place has been recently remodeled and looks quite nice inside, although they have too many tables in a cramped setting, so much so that one of the tables needed to be left empty as no more customers could squeeze in around it.

I'll certainly be back for the pho ga, and maybe the steamed chicken with rice. 

Pro Tip: Please don't put your chili sauce / sriracha directly into the broth. You're disrupting a balance in flavor that took hours to achieve. Put your chili sauce into the small saucer provided, and use as needed!

excerpts: I ordered the chicken with chicken giblets pho ga and nem cua fried imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles and lettuce.
Let me start by saying that the broth from the pho actually tasted like chicken.
The limited spice and fish sauce added to the broth was not too salty and overpowering that it did not take the essential chicken taste away.
The rice noodles were wide and soft.
I normally like my noodles al dente, but in this particularly case, it matched really well with the broth and meat.
Finally, the chicken was pulled and cut into small bite size pieces with a mixture of dark and white meat.
It was a good contrast between the soft and more flavorful dark meat verus the firm but subtle taste of the white meat.
It does not regulate the amount of time the chicken is outdoors, the size of the outdoor space, or its food source.
chicken giblets.author: Chris W.
chicken giblets.review:
Turtle Tower was my introduction to northern-style Vietnamese pho.  Previously, I didn't even know such a thing even existed.  And man was it delicious.  

I ordered the chicken with chicken giblets pho ga and nem cua fried imperial rolls with vermicelli noodles and lettuce.  Let me start by saying that the broth from the pho actually tasted like chicken.  The limited spice and fish sauce added to the broth was not too salty and overpowering that it did not take the essential chicken taste away.  The rice noodles were wide and soft.  I normally like my noodles al dente, but in this particularly case, it matched really well with the broth and meat.  Finally, the chicken was pulled and cut into small bite size pieces with a mixture of dark and white meat.  It was a good contrast between the soft and more flavorful dark meat verus the firm but subtle taste of the white meat.  The giblets added a fulfilling crunch to every bite. 

The nem cua was fried to perfection.  And in this particular case, I could actually taste the crab meat (There are a lot establishments elsewhere that would cheap out and increase the ratio of the pork filling). When eaten with the noodles and lettuce and dipped in the fish sauce, it's elevated to an whole new level.  Definitely recommend trying this dish here at least once.

What's keeping me from giving this 5 stars was that the portion size were too small.  I judge a restaurant by the culinary experience I received versus the amount I paid.  I have no problem giving a shabby "normal" place a perfect score if the value accurately reflects it.  In this case I left the restaurant not hungry but not fulfilled.  In addition I don't think claiming that the chickens were raised "free-ranged" can justify the increase in price.  The USDA states that free-range only means that the animal has access to outdoors.  It does not regulate the amount of time the chicken is outdoors, the size of the outdoor space, or its food source. 

In conclusion I definitely recommend this place to any pho lover.  I'm sure there are many non-Vietnamese people that would appreciate knowing there is a different style of pho out there.  Just don't expect to be stuffed of full when you finish your meal.

chicken giblets.author: Dan B.
chicken giblets.review:
Tonight the muuusic seeems so loud!

We could have lived this daannce forevah,
But nowwwww who's goonnnnna daance with meeee?
Pleeeease staaayy!

...And that was upon only having stepped inside the door.

$4.50 lets you choose 3 of the following to be included in one Vietnamese sandwich: fried egg, grilled chicken, grilled pork, jambon (ham), pate, sausage. I didn't ask, but I figure you can choose the same item for all 3 or do two-and-one if you want.

Note that the sandwich will be JUST the bread and whichever item(s) you select. If you want things that come standard on other restaurants' Vietnamese sandwiches, e.g., mayo, shredded carrots, cilantro, jalapenos, butter, etc., these can be added for $1.55 each.

Yes, each. As an example, think of a standard less-than-$5 chicken Vietnamese sandwich. It has bread, chicken, mayo (or something like it), cilantro, jalapenos, and shredded carrots, all included in the less-than-$5 price. This exact sandwich at Turtle Tower sets you back $10.70. Those following my Vietnamese math will recognize that this amount can get 3 sandwiches at Saigon Sandwich or a whopping 4 at Cam Huong. #justsayin

Another menu notable is the side dish "Long Ga: Chicken Giblets". Upon asking which giblets, I was told it's chicken intestines. A small is $3 and a large is $5. I'm definitely returning at some point to investigate.

ICED TEA: I watched the worker make this. It was a glass filled with 3/4 water then topped off with tea. I'm not talking about a glass of water into which were placed tea bags - this was already-brewed tea added to water. I could still taste the tea, but I thought the watering down aspect was odd.

The worker told me this location opened last year. So I'm guessing the 2007 and 2007-2008 ratings plaques on the wall were for the other locations. Also, there was a Scout Mob deal posted at the register, but I didn't read it.

You know I was,
I was wondering, you know, if
if you could keep on, because
the force, it, it's got a lot of power, and
it make me feel like um
it, it make me feel like uh...
WWOOOOOOO!!!

3 1/2 stars.

excerpts: I also love that they give you the option of ordering a whole plate of rare beef for $4.
I'm surprised that's even legal to serve at a restaurant
but I love adding extra rare beef to my pho at my own pace without worrying about it overcooking.
plate of rare beef.author: Jessica S.
plate of rare beef.review: My favorite pho place in San Francisco. The noodles here are the best and its overall super authentic. I like the chicken pho and imperial rolls a lot. I also love that they give you the option of ordering a whole plate of rare beef for $4. I'm surprised that's even legal to serve at a restaurant but I love adding extra rare beef to my pho at my own pace without worrying about it overcooking.
